					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about" >ABOUT</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      A Brief History of Folklore and Mythology at Harvard                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-1052471" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>The formal awarding of degrees in Folklore and Mythology at Harvard dates to 7 March 1967, when the Faculty of Arts and Sciences unanimously voted in favor of a motion to establish the Committee on Degrees in Folklore and Mythology, the oldest American undergraduate degree program of its kind. <sup>(1)</sup> Those who proposed and spoke in favor of the founding of the Committee on Degrees in Folklore and Mythology at that meeting were Albert B. Lord, Charles Dunn, and Einar Haugen, who also served on the committee in its early years, as did, for example, Frank Cross, Daniel Ingalls, David Maybury-Lewis, David McClellan, Rulan Chao Pian, Eileen Southern, Evon Vogt, John Ward and Cedric Whitman. </p><div><p>In broader terms, however, Harvard’s long engagement with the study of oral literature, of epics and ballads, cosmological and other mythic narratives, popular culture, traditional belief systems and all the many forms of expressive manifestation of culture that constitute the study of folklore and mythology goes back much, much further. And, in fact, there is a direct line that leads from the current generation of Harvard scholars in this field back to that group of distinguished faculty who fashioned the committee, and from them, even further back into the early 1800s; indeed, many of the most storied figures in the history of the University’s commitment to the humanities and interpretive social sciences worked in these fields, among others, Milman Parry, Clyde Kluckhohn, Fred Norris Robinson, George Lyman Kittredge, Francis James Child, and Henry Wadsworth Longfellow. <sup>(2)</sup></p><p>Indeed, it is anything but accidental that the founding of the American Folklore Society, the key professional association in the field in the US, took place at Harvard in the Faculty Room of University Hall on 4 January 1888. <sup>(3)</sup> When some eight decades later, in that same room, the Faculty voted to establish a committee to oversee the awarding of degrees in the field, it was noted that the proposed concentration would be both truly interdisciplinary and would "draw strength from the possibility of designing a wide variety of individual course programs and from the provision of tutorial." That foresighted foundation of the program, based on rigorous methodological training combined with flexible and sympathetic attention to the individual student’s intellectual interests, has proved to be a remarkably durable and successful recipe for the lives and careers of the program’s students. Many of our undergraduates have gone on to take advanced degrees in the many fields for which “Folk &amp; Myth” prepares them and have had outstanding careers in the academy; at the same time, as with all concentrations, the overwhelming majority of former students have had rewarding careers in such disparate fields as medicine, law, business, politics, finance, media, the performing arts, and journalism.</p><p> </p><p> </p><p> </p></div><div> <div><p><a name="footnote1" id="footnote1">(1)</a> Attached please find a facsimile of the minutes of the 7 March 1967 FAS meeting.</p></div><div><p><a name="footnote2" id="footnote2">(2)</a> This branch of Harvard tradition is detailed in David E. Bynum, “Child's Legacy Enlarged: Oral Literary Studies at Harvard since 1856,” <em>Harvard Library Bulletin</em> 22:3 (1974): 1-37, also attached.</p><p><a name="footnote3" id="footnote3">(3)</a> See, for example, the discussion in Stephen A. Mitchell, "HarvardLore: Tradition and Belonging at America's Oldest College," <em>Norveg. The Norwegian Journal of Folklore</em> 43 (2000): 47-65.</p></div><div><p> </p></div></div><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-46766"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about"  class="active-trail active"><span>About</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-189656"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/brief-history-folklore-and-mythology-harvard"  class="active-trail active active"><span>A Brief History of Folklore and Mythology at Harvard</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-48531"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/warren-house" ><span>Warren House</span></a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48536"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/art-credits-site" ><span>Art Credits for SIte</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

		</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&amp;M at 50                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-1013391" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="744" width="1000" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/fm_symposium_poster_revised2.png?m=1499882345&amp;itok=RpepVtrF" alt="" title="" /></p><p>(Please note: this schedule is largely final, but some adjustments and updates may still be made.)</p><p> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"><strong>Thursday March 2</strong></p><p style="margin-left:.5in">5.00     Welcome &amp; opening remarks (Stephen Mitchell, chair)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">5.15     Keynote: "Fifty Years in Folklore" — Robert Teske '70 </p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.15     Dinner</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.15     Performance — Kate Chadbourne (harp)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.30     David Lerner ’88 — MD, Medical Officer at FDA</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.45     Albert Lord / F&amp;M tribute (Gregory Nagy &amp; Joseph Nagy ‘74)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"><strong>Friday March 3</strong></p><p style="margin-left:.5in">8.45     Coffee</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.00     Welcome — Stephen Mitchell</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.05     The Milman Parry Collection - David Elmer</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.30     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; Our Lives</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Deborah Foster</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Katherine Griffis ‘78 — Rev., United Presbyterian Church, Hornell, NY</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Winnie Li ’00 — Author, activist, PhD cand. London School of Economics</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Montana Miller ’96 — Assoc. Prof. of Popular Culture, Bowling Green State University</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Devi Lockwood ’14 — youth delegate with SustainUS to U.N. climate talks in Morocco</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• William Westerman '81 — New Jersey City University</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Louis Monoyudis ’98 — COO, Supply Pod</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">11.30   Performance — Montana Miller ’96 — storytelling, performance</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">12.00   Lunch</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">1:00     Performance — Devi Lockwood ’14 — storytelling</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">1.15     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; the World</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Joseph Nagy '74</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Maja Groff ’01 — Senior Legal Officer at the Permanent Bureau, Hague Conference on Private International Law</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Susan E. Keller ’83 — Assoc. Dean of Academic Affairs, Western State College of Law</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Terrell McSweeny ’97 — Commissioner, Federal Trade Commission</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Ruth Goldstein — Harvard College Fellow and F&amp;M Cttee Member</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Lowell Brower — PhD Cand. in Harvard AAAS and Asst. Head Tutor, F&amp;M</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">3.30     Performance — Becca Nesson ’98 — Berkman Center for Internet &amp; Society, Harvard Law School</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">3.45     Coffee</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">4.00     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; the Future</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Lowell Brower </p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• William Moore ‘85 — Assoc. Professor of American Material Culture, Boston Univ., &amp; Director, American &amp; New England Studies Program</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Merrill Kaplan ‘94 — Assoc. Prof. of Scandinavian Studies and Folklore, Ohio State Univ.</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Lowell Brower — PhD Cand. in Harvard AAAS and Asst. Head Tutor, F&amp;M</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• current students — all juniors and seniors</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.00     Performances — Brendan Bulger ’96 (video); Maggie Harrison ’07 (singing)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.30     Roundtable: current &amp; former chairs &amp; head tutors (Greg Nagy, Joe Harris, Maria Tatar, Steve Mitchell, Hugh Flick, Deborah Foster)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in">            Reception to follow</p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" >2003: &quot;ALL EYEZ ON ME: TUPAC SHAKUR AND THE SEARCH FOR THE MODERN FOLK HERO&quot;</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      "Harvard Gazette: Symposium analyzes, celebrates 'thug'"                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-931226" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="857" width="549" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.15.51_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=gncfh-qj" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="805" width="551" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.07_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=TF_NWe7G" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="701" width="541" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.19_am.png?m=1477329406&amp;itok=EOsTKu1E" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="823" width="551" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.29_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=jY16i3ZI" alt="" title="" /></p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero"  class="active-trail active"><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-170941"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/harvard-gazette-symposium-analyzes-celebrates-thug"  class="active-trail active active"><span>"Harvard Gazette: Symposium analyzes, celebrates 'thug'"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>

      <!--header regions end-->
		
				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-900 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" 		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" >2016: CELEBRATING ANOTHER HARMONY: SOUTH ASIAN FOLKLORE IN THE 21ST CENTURY</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Participant Titles &amp; Abstracts                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-662881" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>**********************</strong></p>
<p><strong>KEYNOTE ADDRESS<br />Friday, April 8, 2016 - 6:00 pm, Barker Center 133</strong></p>
<p>**********************</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Margaret Mills, Ohio State University (Professor Emerita) </p>
<p><em>How Stories Lodge in Lives</em><em> </em></p>
<p>Mary Frere’s <em>Old Deccan Days</em> (1868) introduction to the storyteller, Anna Liberata deSouza, abundantly illustrates how the performer’s choices among traditional stories reflected specific challenges of a personal life full of loss. Frere’s framing of the stories set a model for attention to individual artistry and contexts of performance not again pursued in South Asia till the mid-20<sup>th</sup> century, with the performance turn in folklore studies. In recent decades, Wadley, Gold and Raheja, Narayan, Prasad, Naithani, and Narasamamba, among others, developed text presentations and analyses linking repertoire, performance, and personal history in various ways.  As Ramanujan has pointed out, <em>vrat katha</em> itself is a major ritual genre in which the telling of stories shapes performatively the lives of the tellers and listeners, both in the ostensibly biographical miracle narratives framed within the ritual and the lives of the ritual participants who keep the stories alive. Blackburn’s  <em>Another Harmony</em> itself offered a foundational analysis of relationships of biography, narrative performance genre and ritual efficacy in South Asia.  The present paper reviews trajectories of this complex from biography to ritual studies and ends with some reflections on why the studies of performed narrative in and of lives have more usually, though not exclusively, focused on women protagonists and performers. Are we missing parallels in men’s equally situated narrative performances, or is there a systematic difference in performative focus determined by genre and/or gender?</p>
<p> </p>
<p> _________________________________________________________________________</p>
<p><strong>SYMPOSIUM PANELS</strong><br /><strong>Saturday, April 9, 2016 - 9:00 am - 6:00 pm - Thompson Room, Barker Center</strong></p>
<p></p>
<p align="center"><strong>UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT PANEL</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Aniket De, Tufts University </p>
<p><em>Divided Songs, Altered Gods: Partition, Nationalism, and Performance in the Bengal Borderland</em></p>
<p>This paper studies the history of the Gambhira, a popular performance on either side of the India-Bangladesh border, mainly in Malda (West Bengal) and Rajshahi (Bangladesh). Gambhira originated from rites of the god Hindu Shiva, and later became a popular theatre form in which both Hindu and Muslim performers complained to Shiva, with ridicule, and sarcasm, about people in power. After the Partition of British India in 1947, many Muslim performers fled across the border to East Pakistan (later Bangladesh). The Muslim performers, in Bangladesh’s Islamic context, replaced the figure of Shiva with that of a Muslim farmer, and continued the performance’s older tradition of questioning authority. The paper explores the interaction between broader structural changes in state structure and the consequent impact on folk forms. I explore the realities of such performances in the borderland, as well as the competing historical metanarratives on the changes and continuities in Gambhira.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Benjamin D. Grimm, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Trans-gression: Gender, Divinity, and Cross-dressing in</em><em> the Krishna Līl<em>ā</em>hava</em></p>
<p>The <em>līlahāva </em>– a story in which Krishna and Rādhā exchange clothes during a night of passion – is inflected in poetry, art, and drama, and in its many loci cloaks itself in various symbolic modes: as comedic farce, as amorous play, and as a profound act of devotion. The story is imbued by tense dichotomies of male and female, divine and human, unity and disunity: is it transgressive for a cowherdess to wear Krishna’s peacock-feather crown? If so, from what does this transgression spring? The act of crossdressing exhumes basic tensions between male and female in Hindu thought. Moreover, it leads us to question the very nature of Krishna’s divinity; assuming one another’s identity reveals Rādhā as a mirror of Krishna, suggesting that she is indeed a divine consort, an endemic aspect of his own being. Declaring transgression in the <em>līlahāva </em>emerges from cultural – and thus human – prescriptions for a pair who is incontrovertibly transcendent.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p>Megan Taing, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Brotherhood and Humor: Negotiating the South Asian American College Experience</em>  </p>
<p>This study analyzes the interaction among members of an all-male South Asian American club at an American university, contending that humor is the principle method through which members negotiate bicultural tensions. While seemingly raucous, judgmental, or even discriminatory on the surface, their jokes reveal a deeper sentiment of tolerance and support between members of the club. This mentorship vis-à-vis comedy can be invaluable to some South Asian American males transitioning from a stricter home life to more independence in college – including newfound freedom within the academic and romantic relationship domains. By maintaining membership in a South Asian American brotherhood of sorts, these students are able to retain ties to a familiar part of their identities, the “traditional” upbringing and expectations of their parents, while simultaneously exploring and receiving peer feedback on new interests that could contradict the familiar itself.  </p>
<p></p>
<p align="center"><strong>SOUTH ASIAN FOLKLORE IN HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE</strong></p>
<p> Frank J. Korom, Boston University </p>
<p><em>Three Decades of Folklore Studies in South Asia</em>: <em>Toward a History</em> </p>
<p><em>Another Harmony</em> marked the end of a previous era and signaled a new one in terms of studying South Asian folklore. This paper surveys the past thirty years of folkloristic scholarship on South Asia to identify significant contributions but also to point out gaps in areas of research that demand more and fuller attention. I conclude that while much has been done in the area of verbal art, very little has been done to address material culture. Moreover, the output of work on folklore in South Asia has been predominantly Indocentric, that is to say focusing almost exclusively on India at the expense of that nation’s neighbors in the region. Lastly, an overwhelming majority of the academic literature that one might call “folkloristic” focuses on Hindu traditions, while far less attention has been paid to Islam, and even less on Christianity, Sikhism, Jainism, and Buddhism.</p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p></p>
<p>Adheesh Sathaye, University of British Colombia</p>
<p><em>The Scribal Life of Folktales in Premodern India</em> </p>
<p>This paper will explore how and why, about a thousand years ago, it became popular in India to compile large anthologies of folktales that were told in Sanskrit and disseminated through handwritten manuscripts. Oral variants of these tales are found scattered around the world, and folklorists have long recognized that this diffusion had taken place through an intricate interplay between written and oral modes of transmission. Less understood are the historical motivations for such oral/written interplay, especially within the specific context of the medieval Sanskrit literary culture in which these anthologies were being produced. I propose to sharpen our understanding of the cultural value of folktales in the premodern past, based on the textual history of the <em>Vetāla-pañcaviṃśati</em> (25 Tales of the Animated Corpse) a popular medieval anthology of riddle-tales. I focus on the active role of scribes—both professional and amateur—in carving out a scribal public culture in premodern India, using a combination of folktales, proverbs, and riddles that both complemented and challenged the elite Brahminical intellectual traditions of the time.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p>Leela Prasad, Duke University </p>
<p><em>Nameless in a Great Garden: When English Imperial Conquest Becomes a Purāṇa</em> </p>
<p>My paper will examine a moment on the Indian side of the colonial archive of the anthropology of India to consider an intriguing dramatic poem written by eminent folklorist and literary scholar, P. V. Ramaswami Raju (1852-1897). <em>Sreemat</em> <em>Rajangala Mahodyanam</em>, <em>or The Great Park of The English Raj,</em> is a long poem in Sanskrit with an English translation provided by Raju himself. I will argue that the Raju’s <em>purāṇa</em>-style poem, set in a wondrous garden, operates in two core registers. One register maintains a tension between superlative praise of the English empire and the other is coded criticism about empire itself. I hope to demonstrate that by skillfully incorporating the origin of the English empire (yoked to a narrative about the discovery of America) into a Hindu mythos, Ramaswami Raju is able to project the error of empire as a cosmic error. In this frame, the abrupt ending of the poem, anguished over the namelessness of its protagonist, creates a kind of a moral caesura in the narrative of glory. </p>
<p> <strong> </strong></p>
<p align="center"><strong>SOUTH ASIAN MATERIAL CULTURE &amp; BELIEF</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Joyce Burkhalter Flueckiger, Emory University </p>
<p><em>Standing in Cement: Ravana on the Chhattisgarhi Plains</em> </p>
<p>Over the last two decades, an interdisciplinary focus on the body and visual and material culture has emerged in folklore and religious studies, to counter, in part, the traditional textual/verbal focus of the respective disciplines. This paper is part of a larger study of the agency of materiality in Indian traditions, which analyzes different forms of materiality in ritual and everyday contexts. Here, I focus on the 8-10 foot tall cement images of the <em>rakshasa</em> antagonist Ravana of the Ramayana that are unique to the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh. They stand at village and town centers or on open fields at their outskirts.  Dramatic performances and textual readings are held in front of these images during the festival of Dashera, at the end of which firecrackers are set off around the image to indicate Ravana’s destruction. <em>Narratively</em>, the hero-god Ram kills him; however, <em>materially</em> Ravana lives, standing in cement all year. The permanence of the Ravana physical images creates an alternative theology and worldview to that of verbal epic performances. I argue that the cement Ravanas are <em>material</em> actors.</p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Kirin Narayan, Australian National University </p>
<p><em>Making and Narrating: Vishwakarma Family Stories among Artisans</em><em> </em></p>
<p>Many artisan communities across India trace descent from the Hindu god Vishwakarma, the “Universe Maker.” Identifying themselves by labels marking this family connection—including “Vishwakarmas” or “The Sons of Vishwakarma”—their traditional work was thought to continue their divine ancestor’s making and shaping of the material world. This paper examines themes of making as a form of thinking (Ingold 2013) that pervade the mythology of hereditary artisan castes associated with Vishwakarma (cf. Brouwer 1986). I focus particularly on Gujarat-based family stories and rituals of the goddess Randal Ma, honored as Vishwakarma’s daughter. How, I ask, does this unusually doubled goddess point to larger associations between Vishwakarma kinship, goddess worship, and gendered aspects of making, even as traditional caste occupations have given way to other professions, and the “Make in India” scheme has become a politicized project?</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Puja Sahney, SUNY- Albany </p>
<p><em>Transnational Spaces of Belonging: Immigration Process, Social Ties, and Hindu Homes of Purity  </em><em> </em></p>
<p>This paper discusses the role trans-boundary social and symbolic ties play in shaping the way newly arrived Hindu immigrants from India manage and organize spaces in their suburban American homes around the Hindu notion of “purity.” The focus is on the Hindu domestic shrine, an important religious artifact found in Hindu houses, which influences the movement and behavior of family members and Hindus’ efforts to produce and consume religious spaces within and immediately outside the house. The paper argues that Hindu immigrant homes are transnational spaces of belonging. This transnationality of space is regulated both formally through the lengthy immigration process as well as informally through social ties maintained between people across nations. Using ethnographic data, this paper examines the space-artifact continuum around the notion of purity and how the relationships Hindus build and rebuild with domestic spaces reveal important aspects of their sense of belonging in a new country. </p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Ülo Valk, University of Tartu </p>
<p><em>Where the Goddess Spent her Wedding Night: Place-Lore of the Kāmākhyā Temple in Silghat, Assam</em><em> </em></p>
<p>The paper discusses mythic histories of the temple of Kāmākhyā in Silghat on the southern bank of Brahmaputra in Nagaon district, Assam. It is based on fieldwork, conducted in the temple and the adjacent village intermittently from 2009–2015, concentrating on the stories of three Brahmin families, who have been serving the temple since its establishment in 1745. Especially important is the position of the temple in the mythic landscape of Assam and the strategies of storytelling to enhance its power of narrative gravitation to attract pilgrims. Place-lore about the temple displays some significant discrepancies and disagreements between the narrators who refer to the authority of literary sources but rely on oral traditions of the neighbourhood and on their family histories.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p align="center"><strong>THE POLITICS OF FOLKLORE</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Leah Lowthorp, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Folklore, Politics, and the State: Kutiyattam and National/Global Heritage in India</em> </p>
<p>In recent decades<em>, </em>scholars of South Asian folklore have increasingly engaged the politics of folklore, interrogating its role in both colonialist, nationalist, and other political agendas. This paper considers the role of expressive culture in Indian postcolonial nation building through the lens of Kutiyattam Sanskrit theater of Kerala state, recognized as India’s first UNESCO Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2001. Through an examination of the art’s relationship with India’s national academy for dance, drama, and music, the Sangeet Natak Akademi, it traces state heritage discourse and practice over a fifty year period. It thereby explores the (re)production of the State’s role as arts patron and cultural educator, as well as a sustained state-level promotion of artistic continuity through creative adaptation and change.</p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Shakthi Nataraj, University of California, Berkeley </p>
<p><em>Critical Folkloristics and the Study of Transgender Women’s Communities in South India</em> </p>
<p>Scholars in the emerging field of "critical folkloristics" have criticized notions of folklore that distinguish it from "modern" institutions, emphasizing instead how notions of modernity and traditionality actively shape one another. My research examines the <em>jamath</em> (family) system of Tamil Nadu's <em>thirunangai </em>(transgender woman) communities that has lately become the object of much controversy amongst LGBT activists. Some see these precolonial kinship structures, placing <em>guru</em>s (mentors), above <em>chela</em>s (disciples), as outdated feudal relics, at odds with "modern" notions of equality. Representatives of transnational non-profits similarly argue that <em>jamath</em>s<em> </em>compromise <em>thirunangai'</em>s abilities to effectively make "objective" decisions. Examining narratives of kinship by transgender women that manage and staff a Community Based Organization in Chennai, I argue that the logic of <em>jamath</em> kinship, far from being an outdated relic, both shapes and is shaped by the politics of international LGBT and HIV activism, and the functioning of Community Based Organizations. </p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Finnian Gerety, Brown University </p>
<p><em>The Amplified Sacrifice: Sound, Technology, and Participation in Vedic Rituals in Kerala </em> </p>
<p>For generations, Nambudiri Brahmins of Kerala have performed sacrifices based on liturgies of the first millennium BCE. While their praxis evokes the ideal of an archaic, unchanging sacrifice, the soundscape of Nambudiri ritual culture in recent years has come to reflect technological shifts in Indian society: microphones and megawatt speakers now amplify mantras well beyond the power of the human voice. This paper examines the amplified sacrifice, arguing that local amplification of performances tracks with a regional "amplification" of the cultural prominence of Vedic ritual. This feedback loop increases the participation of non-Nambudiris in the funding, organization, and celebration of such rituals, which are now carried out as festivals with thousands of attendees and a full suite of marketing, media coverage, and VIPs.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

			<div class="at-panel gpanel panel-display footer clearfix">
								<div class="region region-footer-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1389386751" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389386751"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389386751' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><span style="font-size:medium"><strong>FOLKLORE &amp; MYTHOLOGY</strong></span><br />Barker Center, 12 Quincy Street<br />Cambridge, MA  02138<br />617-495-4788</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>								<div class="region region-footer-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1389388220" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389388220"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Last Updated:</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389388220' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	August 09, 2017
</p>
</div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Symposiums &amp; Conferences                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-137976" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Folklore &amp; Mythology holds an annual event aimed at exploring a thematic topic.  These events range from one-day symposia, to multi-day conferences.</p><p> </p><p><img height="744" width="1000" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/fm_symposium_poster_revised2.png?m=1499882345&amp;itok=RpepVtrF" alt="" title="" /></p><p><strong>Folkore and Mythology in and Beyond Harvard: F&amp;M at 50</strong> is a symposium that will be held on Thursday, March 2, 2017 and Friday, March 3, 2017.  See the event page for more details!  (Free and open to the public.)</p><p> </p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390600344" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390600344"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390600344' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168531" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/walters-symposium.jpg?m=1492187826">walters-symposium.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/walters-symposium.jpg?m=1499909549&amp;itok=fFAUKfi7" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-1415209073" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1415209073"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1415209073' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p></p>
<p><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar"></a><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar">Current Calendar</a></p>
<p><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences">Symposiums &amp; Conferences</a><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar"></a></p>
<p></p></div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/"  class="active">The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">

<!--
<ul id="rslides-controls">
</ul>
--></div>
</div></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1390859526" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390859526"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Welcome!</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390859526' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>This is the website for the concentration in Folklore &amp; Mythology at Harvard. </p>
<p></p>
<p>The concentration in Folklore and Mythology is a liberal education in itself, and although most graduates of the program go on to successful careers in medicine, law, business, journalism, and other pursuits, an unusually large number of our alumni and alumnae teach and conduct research in a variety of academic departments. This concentration focuses on the study of society, past or present, through its cultural documents and artifacts, and uses a variety of methodologies drawn from the humanities and social sciences. To concentrate on a society’s folklore and mythology (on sub-national as well as national levels) is to understand its traditional self-definition through its epics, ballads, folktales, legends, beliefs, and other cultural phenomena, including music, song, and dance, and studying a group’s folklore shows how it identifies itself in relation to other groups.</p>
<p>Concentrators conduct independent research on folklore and mythology in a variety of cultures including, for example, African, American, Chinese, Celtic, English, Greek, German, Japanese, Sanskrit &amp; Indian Studies, Scandinavian, and Slavic. Founded in 1967 and the oldest undergraduate degree program in the field in this country, Folklore and Mythology at Harvard has produced many distinguished graduates. Students often form mutually supportive groups; student-faculty contact is by tradition — and structure — very close; and collegiality within the program is highly valued.  (<a href="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/folklore/about">More…</a>)</p>
<p style="text-align:right"></p>
<p style="text-align:right"><em>"Cultures are, after all, collective, untidy assemblages authentificated by belief and agreement, focused only in crisis, systemitized after the fact."</em></p>
<p style="text-align:right">(Barbara Myerhoff, <em>Number Our Days</em>)</p></div></div></div>
  </div></section></div></div>									<div class="region region-content-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1421283854" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1421283854"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">F&amp;M, An Interdisciplinary Approach to Academics &amp; Life</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1421283854' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-407546" class="file file-html file-html-embed">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="">Video</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <div class="file-info"></div><div class="field field-name-field-html-code field-type-text-long field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><iframe src="https://player.vimeo.com/video/114376106" width="440" height="281" frameborder="0" webkitallowfullscreen mozallowfullscreen allowfullscreen></iframe></div></div></div>  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1394143683" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1394143683"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1394143683' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><em>"My professional goals are to make sense of nonsense, find a rationale for the irrational, and seek to make the unconscious conscious."</em></p>
<p style="text-align:right">(Alan Dundes)</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div><section id="block-boxes-1390516924" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390516924"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">What&#039;s New</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390516924' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><a href="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/folklore/whats-new">For the latest updates to the website!</a></p></div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1394143474" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1394143474"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1394143474' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><em>"Fieldwork involving other people is one of the most intensively personal kinds of scholarly research I know."</em></p>
<p style="text-align:right">(Bruce Jackson, <em>Fieldwork</em>)</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>																	</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-931211" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="470" width="243" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.15.21_am.png?m=1477328414&amp;itok=T3oW5m8t" alt="" title="" /></p><p>(image from the Harvard Gazette, April 24, 2003; <a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/harvard-gazette-symposium-analyzes-celebrates-thug?admin_panel=1" title="">click here for the article about the event</a>.)</p><table border="0" cellpadding="3" cellspacing="5"><tr valign="top"><td colspan="4"><p><b>Thursday, April 17th, 2003</b>: </p><p><b>8:00am - 4:00pm - Thompson Room - Barker Center</b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td colspan="4"><p align="center"> </p><p align="center"><b>Keynote Speaker: Professor Michael Eric Dyson</b><br /><b>"Holler If You Hear Me" </b></p><p align="center"><b>Symposium co-sponsored by:</b></p><blockquote><p align="center"><b>The Committee on Degrees in Folklore and Mythology<br />and<br />The Hip-hop Archives of the Dubois Institute</b></p><p align="center"><b>Thompson Room, Barker Center<br />Harvard University<br />12 Quincy Street<br />Cambridge, MA 02138</b></p></blockquote><p> </p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3">The aim of this event is to further dialogue on the role of Tupac Shakur as a visionary and central figure in the imagination of youth, as well as in the landscape of American and global culture. As the title suggests, our goal is to envision and contemplate a new framework that emphasizes Shakur's presence not only as an artist, but as an influential agent in the evolution of contemporary cultural, political and social activism.</td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td colspan="4"><p><b>SCHEDULE</b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Refreshments</b></td><td><b>8:00am– 8:30am</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Introduction</b></td><td><b>8:30am– 9:00am</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Henry Louis Gates, Jr.</td><td colspan="2">–<i> W.E.B. Du Bois Professor of the Humanities, Harvard University.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Stephen Mitchell</td><td colspan="2">– <i>Professor of Scandinavian &amp; Folklore, Harvard University.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Marcyliena Morgan</td><td colspan="2">– <i>Assoc. Professor, Director of Hiphop Archive, Harvard University,   Department of Afro-American Studies.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b><i><b>“All Eyez on Me”: When Visionary Meets the Vision </b></i></b></td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Panel 1</b></td><td><b>9:00am– 10:30am</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Mark Anthony Neal</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Assistant Professor, State University of New York at Albany, Department of English.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>Thug Nigga Intellectual: Tupac as Celebrity Gramscian</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Murray Forman</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Assistant Professor, Northeastern University, Department of Communication Studies.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>Tupac Shakur: O.G. (Ostensibly Gone) </i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Knut Aukrust</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Professor of Culture Studies, University of Oslo, Visiting Scholar in the Department of Folklore at Harvard University. </i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>“Tired Of Hearin' These Voices In My Head”: Bakhtin’s MC Battle</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Break</b></td><td><b>10:30am - 10:50am</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Panel 2</b></td><td><b>10:50am - 12:00am</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Emmett Price</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Assistant Professor, Northeastern University, Departments of Music and African American Studies.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>From Thug Life to Legend: The Realization of a Black Folk Hero</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Greg Dimitriadis</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Assistant Professor, University of Buffalo, Graduate School of Education.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>Talking about Tupac: Young People’s Perspectives on his Life, Death, and Discursive Rebirth</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Cheryl Keyes</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Associate Professor, University of California, Los Angeles, Department of Ethnomusicology.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>Redefining the Meaning of Hero in Hiphop Culture: The Case of Tupac Shakur</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Lunch</b></td><td><b>12:00pm - 2:00pm</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>KEYNOTE ADDRESS:</b></td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Michael Eric Dyson</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Avalon Professor in the Humanities and African American Studies, University of Pennsylvania.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>“Holler if You Hear Me”</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>PERFORMANCE:</b></td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Nicole Hodges</td><td colspan="2"><i>– University of Southern California, Department of American Studies and Ethnicity.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>The Death of the Last Blackman in the Entire Universe: The Re-Mix </i></b></p></td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Panel 3</b></td><td><b>2:00pm - 3:30pm</b></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Lawrence Bobo</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Norman Tishman and Charles M. Diker Professor of Sociology and Afro-American Studies, Harvard University.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>“Let Knowledge Drop”: Tupac Shakur and the Power of the Black Mind</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Dionne Bennett </td><td colspan="2"><i>– University of California, Los Angeles, Department of Anthropology.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>"How Do We Want It?": Feminism, the Politics of Empathy, and the Legacy of Tupac Shakur</i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td>Bakari Kitwana</td><td colspan="2"><i>– Author and Adjunct Professor, Kent State University, Department of Political Science.</i></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="3"><p style="margin-left:40px"><b><i>“Ride or Die”: Building Bridges between Hip-Hop and Black Power </i></b></p></td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"> </td><td> </td></tr><tr valign="top"><td> </td><td colspan="2"><b>Closing</b></td><td><b>3:30pm - 4:00pm</b></td></tr></table><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century"   <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389386751' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><span style="font-size:medium"><strong>FOLKLORE &amp; MYTHOLOGY</strong></span><br />Barker Center, 12 Quincy Street<br />Cambridge, MA  02138<br />617-495-4788</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>								<div class="region region-footer-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1389388220" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389388220"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Last Updated:</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389388220' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	August 09, 2017
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1389395993" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389395993"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389395993' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>     </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-solr-search-box" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_search_solr_search_box no-title"  module="boxes" delta="solr_search_box"><div class="block-inner clearfix">
