		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138066" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_1">
<div class="text-content style_External_670_140">
<div class="style">
<p class="Header"><span class="style_1">FIRE ON THE MOUNTAIN</span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style">A BLUEGRASS SYMPOSIUM</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_3">
<div class="text-content style_External_634_49 vertical-align-middle-middlebox">
<div class="style_2 vertical-align-middle-innerbox">
<p class="paragraph_style_1">SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 2010</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_4">
<div class="text-content graphic_textbox_layout_style_default_External_609_1616">
<div class="graphic_textbox_layout_style_default">
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Thompson Room, Barker Center<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">12 Quincy Street, Cambridge, MA<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Harvard University<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">For pictures from this event please click </span><a class="class1" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~folkmyth/Folk_%26_Myth/Bluegrass_Pictures.html" title="Bluegrass_Pictures.html"><span class="style_5">here</span></a><span class="style_4">.</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_6">Free and open to the public; no tickets required.</span><span class="style_7"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><a class="class2" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~folkmyth/Folk_%26_Myth/Bluegrass_Directions.html" title="Bluegrass_Directions.html">(Directions &amp; Important Information)</a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_7"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_7">Sponsored by the Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology, the </span><a class="class3" href="http://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/" title="http://ofa.fas.harvard.edu/"><span class="style_8">Office for the Arts at Harvard</span></a><span class="style_7"> (OFA), the Office of the Provost, the Undergraduate Council, the Department of Music, and the Harvard College American Music Association (HCAMA)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_10">(</span><span class="style_11">Note:</span><span class="style_10"> this is a draft schedule; some aspects may change, or be clarified, as the event approaches.)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">10:30 am     Welcome and Coffee<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">10:45 am     Introductory Remarks</span><span class="style_9">                      <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                          Deborah Foster &amp; Forrest O’Connor<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">11:00 am     Keynote Address<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_13">                          </span><span class="style_9">Matt Glaser</span><span class="style_14"> (Berklee School of Music, American Roots Music Program)<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">11:30 am     Bluegrass: Its Roots and Branches<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">Historians, ethnomusicologists, and academically inclined performers consider the <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">history</span><span class="style_9"> </span><span class="style_15">of bluegrass: its diverse (and controversial) roots, its major proponents, its <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">evolution, and its possible future.</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Neil Rosenberg </span><span class="style_14">(Memorial University of Newfoundland)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Jack Tottle </span><span class="style_14">(East Tennessee State University)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Michelle Kisliuk </span><span class="style_14">(University of Virginia)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">                         Alison Brown ’84 <span class="style_16">(Bluegrass musician, Compass Records)</span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">                         Garry West <span class="style_16">(Bluegrass musician, Compass Records)</span>                               </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6">                               </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">                         Scott Alarik (moderator) <span class="style_16">(Folk music writer, Boston Globe)</span>                               </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">1:00 pm      The Video Oral History Project<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><span class="style_17">                         </span>The International Bluegrass Music Museum’s role in preserving the history and </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><span class="style_17">                         </span>growing the future of Bluegrass music worldwide. Presented by Gabrielle Gray, </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><span class="style_17">                         </span>Executive Director, and Drs. Richard Brown and Peter Salovey, Museum Trustees.</p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">1:15 pm      Light Lunch for Attendees<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">2:15 pm      The Instruments of Bluegrass: Craft to Sound<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         </span><span class="style_15">Renowned guitar- and mandolin-maker Lynn Dudenbostel discusses his craft (and <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         </span><span class="style_15">the ways in which it relates to bluegrass), and displays actual samples of his work. <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         </span><span class="style_15">Afterward,  Forrest O’Connor presents his undergraduate thesis on luthiery, and Sam <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         </span><span class="style_15">Bush test-drives a Dudenbostel F-5.</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Lynn Dudenbostel </span><span class="style_14">(Dudenbostel Stringed Instruments)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Forrest O’Connor ’10 </span><span class="style_14">(Harvard University)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Sam Bush </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician, TG2 Artists)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">3:00 pm      Coffee Break<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">3:30 pm      Contemporary Bluegrass: A Discussion with Musicians<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">Leading bluegrass musicians consider (and demonstrate examples of) songs in the <br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">bluegrass repertoire that have heavily influenced them. They also discuss their careers,<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        </span><span class="style_15">creative processes, current projects and future plans.<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Alison Brown ’84 </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician, Compass Records)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Sam Bush </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician, TG2 Artists)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Bobby Hicks </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                         Jack Tottle (moderator) </span><span class="style_14">(East Tennessee State University)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">5:00 pm      Dinner Break<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_12">7-8:30 pm  Evening Performance<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        Clint Miller ’11</span><span class="style_14">(Harvard University) </span><span class="style_9">opening<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        Alison Brown ’84 </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician, Compass Records)</span><span class="style_9"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        Sam Bush </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician, TG2 Artists)<br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9"> </span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_9">                        Bobby Hicks </span><span class="style_14">(Bluegrass musician)</span></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

      <h2 class="block-title">Last Updated:</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389388220' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	August 09, 2017
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1389395993" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389395993"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-solr_search_box' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><form class="search-block-form" action="/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2010: Singers &amp; Tales in the 21st Century                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138056" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke">
<div class="text-content style_External_560_337">
<div class="style">
<p class="paragraph_style">Singers &amp; Tales </p>
<p class="paragraph_style">in the 21st Century:</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_1">The Legacies of Milman Parry <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_1">and Albert Lord<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2">December 3 - 5, 2010</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="tinyText style_SkipStroke_1 stroke_0"></div>
</div>
<div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_2">
<div class="text-content graphic_shape_layout_style_default_External_592_2077">
<div class="graphic_shape_layout_style_default">
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3">Further information about the Symposium can be found on the </span><a class="class1" href="http://chs119.chs.harvard.edu/mpc/" title="http://chs119.chs.harvard.edu/mpc/"><span class="style_3">Milman Parry Collection website</span></a><span class="style_3">, including an email address for registration (free) and information on area hotels.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3">Unless otherwise noted, all events will take place in the Fong Auditorium, Boylston Hall.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_5">Friday, December 3</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">9:15-9:30    </span><span class="style_4">Registration<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">9:30-9:45    </span><span class="style_4">Opening remarks</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">9:45-11:15    </span><span class="style_4">Formula and Theme </span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Egbert Bakker, “Homeric Formulas and the Intertextuality Continuum”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Carl Lindahl, “The Porous House Sequence in Appalachian Folktales”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Chao Gejin, “Current Trends in Chinese Folkloristics: A Perspective from <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                the Localized Application of the Oral-Formulaic Theory”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">10:30-10:45    </span><span class="style_4">Coffee Break</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Coffee and snacks in Ticknor Lounge, Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">11:30-12:30    </span><span class="style_4">Homer</span><span class="style_6"> <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Minna Skafte Jensen, “Menelaus in the </span><span class="style_3">Odyssey</span><span class="style_6">: A Study in Patterned Narrative”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Françoise Létoublon, “The Trojan Formulaic Theater”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">12:30-2:00    </span><span class="style_4">Lunch</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Lunch for conference speakers in Warren House</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">2:00-4:00    </span><span class="style_4">Balkan Epics</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        John Miles Foley, “Oral Epic in Stolac: Collective Tradition and Individual Art”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Mirsad Kunić, “The Death of the Hero Mustaj Bey of the Lika in the Songs of the<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Milman Parry Collection”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Ronelle Alexander, “Tracking the Epic Register in South Slavic”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Nicola Scaldaferri / Zymer Neziri, “From the Archive to the Field: New <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Research on Albanian Epic Songs”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><span class="style_6">4:30-5:30    </span><span class="style_4">Reception and Exhibition</span><span class="style_6"> <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Amy Lowell Room, Houghton Library, Second Floor</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">6:00-7:00    </span><span class="style_4">Performance by Odhon Bayar<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Ticknor Lounge, Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">7:30    </span><span class="style_4">Dinner for Conference Speakers / Performers</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Harvard Faculty Club</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_5">Saturday, December 4</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">9:00-10:30    </span><span class="style_4">Comparative Approaches I</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Nikolay Grintser, “Common Grief: Weeping Over Hector and Rama”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Olga Levaniouk, “The Dreams of Barchin and Penelope”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Holly Davidson, “The Written Text as a Metaphor for the Integrity of Oral <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Composition in Iranian Traditions and Beyond”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">10:30-10:45    </span><span class="style_4">Coffee Break</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Coffee and snacks in Ticknor Lounge, Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">10:45-11:45    </span><span class="style_4">Comparative Approaches II</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Anna Bonifazi / David Elmer, “Visuality in South Slavic and Homeric Epic”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Joseph Nagy, “Snakes of the Heart in Serbian and Irish Heroic Tale”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">11:45-12:00     </span><span class="style_4">Coffee Break</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Coffee and snacks in the Department of the Classics, Boylston Hall 2</span><span class="style_7">nd</span><span class="style_3"> floor<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">12:00-1:00    </span><span class="style_4">Technologies</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Peter McMurray, “There Are No Oral Media? Aural and Visual Perceptions of <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                South Slavic Epic Poetry”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Casey Dué / Mary Ebbott, “Multitext as an Extension of the Theory and <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Fieldwork of Parry (and Lord)”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">1:00-2:15    </span><span class="style_4">Lunch</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Lunch for conference speakers in Warren House</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">2:15-3:15    </span><span class="style_4">Memory</span><span class="style_6"> <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        David Bouvier, “Formulaic Expressions and Memory in Homer”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Carlo Severi, “Composition in the Mind: Iconography, Orality, and the <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Anthropology of Memory”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">3:15-3:30    </span><span class="style_4">Coffee Break</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Coffee and snacks in the Classics Dept., Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">3:30-5:00    </span><span class="style_4">Music and Performance</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        John Franklin, “South Slavic Heroic Melody: Towards a New Method of <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Analysis”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Dwight Reynolds, “Composition in Performance Arab Style” <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Karl Reichl, “The Singing of Tales: The Role of Music in Epic Performance and <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                in the Edited Text”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">5:30-6:30    </span><span class="style_4">Performance by Âşık Şeref Taşlıova</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Ticknor Lounge, Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">8:00    </span><span class="style_4">Dinner for Conference Speakers / Performers</span><span class="style_6"> <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Ilex Foundation, 82 Revere St., Boston</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_5">Sunday, December 5</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">9:00-10:30    </span><span class="style_4">Scandinavian Traditions</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Lars Lönnroth, “Old Norse Texts as Performance”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Gísli Sigurðsson, “The Oral Background of the Eddas and Sagas”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Tom DuBois, “Yearning for Multimedia Before Its Time”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">10:30-10:45    </span><span class="style_4">Coffee Break</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Coffee and snacks in Ticknor Lounge, Boylston Hall<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">10:45-12:15    </span><span class="style_4">Dialogic Approaches</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Anna Stavrakopoulou, “Dialogue of the Deaf: Puppeteers vs. Interviewers on <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Oral History and Historical Data”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Aida Vidan, “The Ballad of a Lost Sibling: Oral Sources of Croatian Renaissance <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Drama”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Lotte Tarkka, “Dialogue of Genres in Kalevala Meter Oral Poetry”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">12:15-2:00    </span><span class="style_4">Lunch</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">        Lunch for conference speakers in Warren House</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">2:00-3:00    </span><span class="style_4">Epic and Society</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Susan Niditch, “Preserving Traditions of ‘Them’ and the Creation of ‘Us’: <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Formulaic Language, Historiography, Mythology, and Self-Definition”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">        Margaret Beissinger, “Transgression, Shame, and the Upholding of Traditional <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_6">                Society: Incest in Balkan Oral Epic”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_6">3:00-3:30    </span><span class="style_4">Closing Remarks</span></p>
</div>
</div>

  </article>

Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2011: African Dance Diaspora                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138071" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="style_SkipStroke_2">
<div class="text-content Normal_External_611_78">
<div class="Normal">
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style">African Dance Diaspora</span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1">A symposium on Embodied Knowledge</p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_2">
<div class="text-content Normal_External_607_4299">
<div class="Normal">
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_1">Friday, March 25</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">3:15<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">WELCOME</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Ingrid Monson &amp; Deborah Foster (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">3:30 - 4:30<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">OPENING GAMBIT: </span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Move Your Words”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Elizabeth McAlister (</span><span class="style_4">Wesleyan University</span><span class="style_3">) &amp; Lovely Nicolas<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">5:00 - 6:30 <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">MOVEMENT WORKSHOP: </span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">How We Got to the Funk  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Jawole Willa Jo Zollar, </span><span class="style_4">Founder and Artistic Director of Urban Bush Women</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">Break for Dinner</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">8:00 - 9:30 <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">FILM SCREENING: NORA </span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">followed by a panel discussion with:<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Alla Kovgan (</span><span class="style_4">NORA Co-director</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Jawole Willa Jo Zollar (</span><span class="style_4">Urban Bush Women</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Robb Moss (</span><span class="style_4">Documentary Film Maker, Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Joan Frosch (</span><span class="style_4">University of Florida</span><span class="style_3">)</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_1">Saturday, March 26</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">9:30<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">WELCOME &amp; INTRODUCTION</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">9:45 - 11:00<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">EMBODIED KNOWLEDGE</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Moderated by: Brenda Dixon-Gottschild  (</span><span class="style_4">Temple University, Emerita</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Yvonne Daniel (</span><span class="style_4">Smith College, Emerita</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“The Ritual Classroom”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Nadine George-Graves (</span><span class="style_4">UC-San Diego</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Elementary School Meets Performance Theory: Blackness, Diaspora and Spidering <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">in the 21st Century”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">John C. McCall (</span><span class="style_4">Univ. of Southern Illinois</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“The Signifying Leopard: Understanding Ekpe’s ‘Body of Knowledge’”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Carrie Noland (</span><span class="style_4">UC-Irvine</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Poetry and Performance”</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">11:15 - 1:00 <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">BODIES IN TIME: Synchrony in Music &amp; Dance</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Moderated by: Kay Kaufman Shelemay  (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Corinna Campbell (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Personalizing Tradition: Performing Daily Life in Surinamese Maroon Folkloric Dance”</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Katherine Hagedorn (</span><span class="style_4">Pomona College</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Mole Yansa: Embodying the Sacred Knowledge of Babalú-Ayé”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Carla Martin (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Between Two Cultures: Language, Music, and Hybrid Identity in Sara Tavares     <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Urban Cape Verdean Diaspora”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Ingrid Monson (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Jazz and Embodied Knowledge”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Patty Tang (</span><span class="style_4">MIT</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Bàkks in Motion”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">Break for Lunch</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">2:00 - 3:30<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">AFRICAN DANCE: Migration &amp; Cultural Transmission</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Moderated by: Thomas F. DeFrantz (</span><span class="style_4">MIT</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Esailama Diouf (</span><span class="style_4">Northwestern University</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">”SAUCE!: Kitchen Conversations about Dance and Cultural Knowledge”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Habib Iddrisu (</span><span class="style_4">Northwestern University</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“From the Wellspring of Dagbon Village to International Stage: Understanding the Journey of Baamaaya Music and Dance”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Sharon Kivenko (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Watching and Doing: Pedagogies of Performance and Practice in Malian Dance”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Mecca Zabriskie (</span><span class="style_4">Northwestern University</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Quilted Embodiments: Dancing as a Way Back Home and Beyond”</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">4:00 - 5:30<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">MASTERCLASS: </span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Ronald K. Brown, <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">founder and Artistic Director of Evidence, A Dance Company</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">Break for Dinner</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_1">Saturday Evening</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">8:00 - 9:30<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">DANCE THE DIALOGUE: Performances &amp; Roundtable Discussion</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Ronald K. Brown (</span><span class="style_4">Evidence, A Dance Company, NYC</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Prayer and Celebration”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Thomas F. DeFrantz (</span><span class="style_4">MIT</span><span class="style_3">, </span><span class="style_4">Slippage:Performance/Culture/Technology</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Excerpts from “Monk’s Mood: A Performance Meditation on the Life and Music of <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Thelonious Monk”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Cynthia Oliver (</span><span class="style_4">COCo Dance Theatre, Univ. of Illinois, Urbana-Champaign</span><span class="style_3">) <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“Calypso: An Agent of Caribbean Diasporic Communion”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Zab Maboungou (</span><span class="style_4">Zab Maboungou / Compagnie de Danse Nyata Nyata, Montreal</span><span class="style_3">)  <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">“De/liberated Gestures”</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">10:00 - 1:00 <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">UHURU AFRIKA DANCE CELEBRATION</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">@ CAMBRIDGE QUEEN’S HEAD</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Featuring Malinké balafonist Balla Kouyaté</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_1">Sunday, March 27</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">10:00 - 12:00<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">DANCE WORKSHOP: </span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Lacina Coulibaly (</span><span class="style_4">Yale University</span><span class="style_3">) and Sidi Mohamed “Joh” Camara (</span><span class="style_4">Troupe Sewa, Boston</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">12:15 - 1:15              <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">NEW DIRECTIONS: An Open Conversation and Performance Excerpt*</span><span class="style_3"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Moderated by: Deborah Foster &amp; Joan Frosch <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Michelle Bach-Coulibaly (</span><span class="style_4">Brown University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">De Ama Battle (</span><span class="style_4">Art of Black Dance &amp; Music</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Sidi Mohamed “Joh” Camara (</span><span class="style_4">Boston</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">*Emily Coates (</span><span class="style_4">Yale University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">*Lacina Coulibaly (</span><span class="style_4">Yale University</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Fatou-Carol Sylla (</span><span class="style_4">Boston</span><span class="style_3">)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Grete Viddal (</span><span class="style_4">Harvard University</span><span class="style_3">)</span></p>
</div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>

Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li 					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2012: Grimm Legacies                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138076" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>GRIMM LEGACIES</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Friday, February 3rd:</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">4:00 – 5:00 pm</span><span class="style_4"> –   </span><span class="style_6">“Fairy Tales in a Digital Age</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">                                Heidi Anne Heiner of Sur La Lune Fairy Tales<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                The world has changed considerably since Jacob and Wilhelm Grimm first<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                published their märchen 200 years ago. The past twenty years have especially<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                seen a significant change in how fairy tales are disseminated to a worldwide<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                audience. Come hear the history of SurLaLune Fairy Tales as well as the plans <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                for its future as we strive to understand and share our rich folkloric past with<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                current and future generations. From statistics to art to trolls, we'll also discuss<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">                                the changing perceptions and visibility of beloved tales.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">5:30 – 7:00 pm</span><span class="style_4"> – </span><span class="style_7">Jack Zipes, Keynote Speaker</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">        “Two Hundred Years after Once Upon a Time: The Legacy of the <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">        Brothers Grimm and their Tales in Germany”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Saturday, February 4th:</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">8:45 - 9:00 am – Coffee<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">9:00 - 9:15 am</span><span class="style_6"> – Welcome by Maria Tatar<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_8">                                “Magical and Mythical: 200 Years of the Brothers Grimm”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">9:15 - 11:15 am - INTO THE WOODS<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Cara Zimmerman<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Henry Darger, Adolf Wolfli, and Tales of Violence in Outsider Art”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">David Rice<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“When the Forest Becomes the Woods: The Horror Effect in the Grimms; Hansel and Gretel and Beyond”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Megan Leroy<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Domestic Adaptations: Anne Sexton’s </span><span class="style_9">Transformations</span><span class="style_4"> and the Grimms’ Tales”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">11:30 - 1:00 pm - UNDER THE KNIFE<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Valerie Gribben<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Medicine and Märchen”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Ariane Mandell<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Empowered by Tears: Weeping in Grimm’s Fairy Tales”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Perri Klass<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Grimm and the Experts:  Psychiatrists, Pediatricians, and Pundits”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">1:00 - 1:45 pm - Lunch<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">1:45 - 2:15 pm – Short Films<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">2:15 - 3:45 pm - AMONG THE BEASTS </span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Ruth Lingford<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Animating the Grimms”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">David Elmer<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“The Metamorphosis of a Folktale: 'Beauty and the Beast' in Apuleius' </span><span class="style_9">Metamorphoses.</span><span class="style_4">"<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Jerry Griswold<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“The Many Conclusions of ‘Beauty and the Beast’”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">4:00 - 5:45 pm - THROUGH THE MAGIC MIRROR<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">John Cech<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“The Grimms, Sendak, and the Zeitgeist”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Michael Hearn<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">"Increasing the Happiness of Children:  George Cruikshank Illustrates the Brothers Grimm" <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Kate Bernheimer<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">"The Grimm Art of Fairy-Tale Editorship"<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">Claudia Schwabe<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">“Between Socialism and Snow White: GDR Fairy Tales”<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">5:45 - 6:30 pm - Wrap Up</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390600736' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168546" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/frog_king.jpg?m=1492187827">frog_king.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/frog_king.jpg?m=1499746908&amp;itok=6cFy8iPP" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">
		<!-- Three column 3x33 Gpanel -->
		
			<div class="at-panel gpanel panel-display footer clearfix">
								<div class="region region-footer-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1389386751" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389386751"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389386751' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><span style="font-size:medium"><strong>FOLKLORE &amp; MYTHOLOGY</strong></span><br />Barker Center, 12 Quincy Street<br />Cambridge, MA  02138<br />617-495-4788</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>								<div class="region region-footer-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1389388220" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389388220"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

	August 09, 2017

			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138086" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><div class="style_SkipStroke_2">
<div class="text-content graphic_textbox_layout_style_default_External_650_4100">
<div class="graphic_textbox_layout_style_default">
<h3 style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">Wednesday 30 October</span></h3>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Keynote</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">17.00-17.15         Welcome</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">17.15-18.30         SCHJØDT</span><span class="style_2"> Jens Peter (Aarhus) “Pre-Christian Religion of the North and the Need for Comparativism: Reflections on Why, How, and with What We Can Compare” [1]</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">18.30-20.00         Reception and Exhibition of Old Norse Materials at Harvard: Houghton Library</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">20.00-20.30         HUGHES</span><span class="style_2"> Shaun F.D. (Purdue) “The Icelandic Manuscripts at Houghton Library” [2]</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_1"> </span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_4"></p>
<h3 style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">Thursday 31 October</span></h3>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_1"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Thursday - Panel One</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">08.30-09.00         Welcome and Dean Sorensen’s remarks</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">09.00-09.30         DUBOIS</span><span class="style_3"> Thomas A. (UWisconsin) “Nordic Mythologies: An Areal Perspective”</span><span class="style_4">[3]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">09.30-10.00         LINDOW</span><span class="style_3"> John (UC Berkeley/Uppsala) “Comparing Finnish/Karelian and Nordic Mythologies”</span><span class="style_4">[4]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">10.00-10.30         COLE</span><span class="style_3"> Richard (University College London/Harvard) “Snorri and the Jews”</span><span class="style_4">[5]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">10.30-11.00         COFFEE BREAK</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Thursday - Panel 2</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">11.00-11.30         HERMANN</span><span class="style_3"> Pernille (Aarhus) “Memory and Old Norse Mythic Texts”</span><span class="style_4">[6]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">11.30-12.00         HESLOP</span><span class="style_3"> Kate (Zürich) “Twice-Told Tales: Framing Mytho-Heroic Narrative in Textual and Visual Media”</span><span class="style_4">[7]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">12.00-12.30         GLAUSER</span><span class="style_3"> Jürg (Zürich and Basel) “Meads and Media of Myths”</span><span class="style_4">[8]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_2">14.00-14.30         KAPLAN</span><span class="style_3"> Merrill (Ohio State Univ) “</span><span class="style_5">Vǫlsa þáttr</span><span class="style_3">: Making Paganism”</span><span class="style_4">[9]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">14.30-15.00         GUNNELL</span><span class="style_3"> Terry (Háskóli Íslands) “</span><span class="style_5">Blótgyðjur, Goðar, Mimi</span><span class="style_3">, Incest and Wagons: Oral Memories of the Religion of the Vanir”</span><span class="style_4">[10]</span><span class="style_3">                                        </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">15.00-15.30         JÓHANNA</span><span class="style_3"> Katrín Friðriksdóttir (Harvard / Stofnun Árna Magnússonar) “Literary Reworkings of Norse Mythology: The Afterlife of the Norse Gods in Late Medieval Icelandic </span><span class="style_5">rímur</span><span class="style_3">”</span><span class="style_4">[11]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">16.00-16.30         WELLENDORF </span><span class="style_3">Jonas (UC Berkeley) “The Æsir and their Idols”</span><span class="style_4">[12]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">16.30-17.00         SAMPLONIUS</span><span class="style_3"> Kees (Amsterdam) “Magic Wands and Mighty </span><span class="style_5">vǫlur</span><span class="style_3">: The Search for Scandinavian Paganism”</span><span class="style_4">[13]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">17.00-17.30         ZACHRISSON</span><span class="style_3"> Torun (Stockholm) “Völund was Here: An Archaeologically-Anchored Myth”</span><span class="style_4">[14]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>

<h3 style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_1">Friday 1 November</span></h3>

<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">09.00-09.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">PUETT</span><span class="style_3"> Michael (Harvard) “Thinking about Old Norse Mythology from a Comparative Perspective” </span><span class="style_4">[15]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">09.30-10.00</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">NAGY</span><span class="style_3"> Joseph (UCLA) “Vermin Gone Bad in Scandinavian and Other Traditions”</span><span class="style_4">[16]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">10.00-10.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">WITZEL</span><span class="style_3"> Michael (Harvard) “Ymir in India, China — and Beyond”</span><span class="style_4">[17]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
