<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Friday - Panel 2</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">11.00-11.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">GUÐRÚN</span><span class="style_3"> Nordal (Háskóli Íslands / Stofnun Árna Magnússonar) “</span><span class="style_5">Grímnismál</span><span class="style_3">: A Text in the Thirteenth Century”</span><span class="style_4">[18]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">11.30-12.00</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">BÄCKVALL</span><span class="style_3"> Maja (Harvard) “Myths Lost and Found in the Uppsala </span><span class="style_5">Edda</span><span class="style_3">”</span><span class="style_4">[19]</span><span class="style_3">  </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">12.00-12.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">LYLE</span><span class="style_3"> Emily (Edinburgh) "Baldr and Iraj: Murdered and Avenged”</span><span class="style_4">[20]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">12.30-14.00         LUNCH BREAK</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Friday - Panel 3</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">14.00-14.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">SUNDQVIST</span><span class="style_3"> Olof (Gävle) ”The Temple, the Tree and the Well. A </span><span class="style_5">topos</span><span class="style_3"> or Real Cosmic Symbolism at Cultic sites in Pre-Christian Northern Europe?”</span><span class="style_4">[21]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">14.30-15.00</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">PATTON</span><span class="style_3"> Kimberley (Harvard) “That Tree Set Up in Wisdom: Yggdrasil, The Tree of the Cross, and the Upside-Down Tree of the Vedic Traditions”</span><span class="style_4">[22]</span><span class="style_3"> </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">15.00-15.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">RÖSLI</span><span class="style_3"> Lukas (Zürich) “Rethinking the End of the World in Old Norse Mythology”</span><span class="style_4">[23]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">15.30-16.00         COFFEE BREAK</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">Friday - Panel 4</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">16.00-16.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">NORDVIG</span><span class="style_3"> Matthias (Aarhus) “A Hot Topic: Volcanoes in Old Norse Mythology”</span><span class="style_4">[24]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">16.30-17.00</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">ABRAM</span><span class="style_3"> Chris (Notre Dame) “</span><span class="style_5">Ragnarök</span><span class="style_3"> and Climate Change: Reading </span><span class="style_5">Völuspá</span><span class="style_3"> at the End of the World”</span><span class="style_4">[25]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_2">17.00-17.30</span><span class="style_3">         </span><span class="style_2">PRICE</span><span class="style_3"> Neil (Aberdeen) “Archaeologies of the </span><span class="style_5">Ragnarök</span><span class="style_3">: A Sixth-Century Climate Disaster and its Geomythological Legacy”</span><span class="style_4">[26]</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_3">--------</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_2">17.30-18.30         RECEPTION</span></strong><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3"> </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3"> </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="Free_Form"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_6"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[1]</span><span class="style_3"> Schjødt: “As anybody the least familiar with the pre-Christian religion of the North (PCRN) will know the source situation in this field is far from ideal: some sources are very hard to interpret and to date, and others are demonstrably written in the Christian Middle Ages by Christian authors. This situation creates a clear need for having a model of the ‘type’ of religion to which PCRN belongs. The problem which will be discussed in the lecture, is thus how we create such a model. There is no doubt that some sort of comparative enterprise is needed, but how would it be meaningful to apply ‘the comparative method’ in relation to PCRN?”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[2]</span><span class="style_3"> Hughes: “In his introductory remarks opening the exhibition, “Icelandic Sagas, Eddas, and Art,” held at the Pierpont Morgan Library in 1982, the late Charles Ryskamp, then Director of that august institution,  noted that while his library had a formidable and extensive collection of manuscripts, it did not have a single Icelandic one. The Houghton Library possesses 57.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_3">                  The first manuscript was given to the College Library in 1886, and for many decades it was catalogued as a book (Scan.4200.3) before final receiving the designation “MS Icel. 55.” It was Henry Wadsworth Longfellow (1807-1882) who began the College’s investment in Scandinavian Studies with the purchase of 650 volumes from Denmark and Sweden in the year before he became Smith Professor</span><span class="style_5"> </span><span class="style_3">of Modern Languages, a position he held from 1836-1854, but it was not until 1893 when Archibald Cary Coolidge (1866-1928) began to teach a half course on Scandinavian History every other year, that Scandinavian Studies can be said to have taken root at Harvard. Coolidge was joined by William Henry Schofield (1870-1920), Instructor in English 1897-1902 (later Professor of Comparative Literature, 1906-1920), who taught the first course in Old Norse in 1900. It was Coolidge who was responsible for engineering in 1904 the purchase of some 10,000 volumes from the library of Konrad von Maurer (1823-1902), Professor of Law at the University of Munich 1847-1888. In the “Zweiter (Nordischer) Teil” of the printed catalog to Maurer’s library, items 2353-2356 are manuscripts. The first three are copies of </span><span class="style_5">Jónsbók, </span><span class="style_3">two in vellum, now catalogued as MS Icel. 42, 43, and 46. The fourth item, number 2356, lists: “Manuskripte. 39 altnordische Codices (Papierhandschriften) juristischen, theologischen, poetischen und folkloristischen Inhalts.” These were manuscripts that Maurer collected during his journey to Iceland in the summer of 1858. But as the ancients said, “caveat emptor.” This description is only partly correct. To begin with, these manuscripts are not Old Norse, they are early Modern Icelandic, some written as late as the first decade of the nineteenth century, and while they may be characterized as “legal, theological, poetical and folkloristic,” they are in fact much more varied.  This paper looks at some of the highlights of the Maurer collection and those manuscripts that were added later, focusing on those that are likely to be of interest to Old Norse scholars, but not neglecting their variety and their importance to modern as well as medieval scholars.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[3]</span><span class="style_3"> DuBois: “Old Norse materials regarding the sun present conflcting stories about its identity and nature.  My paper looks at folk song materials from among Sami, Finns, and Latvians to investigate to what extent a shared mythic narrative of a female sun (or sun's daughter) may have existed as a common element in Nordic/Baltic mythologies and whether that figure enters into marriage with other astral figures (e.g., the moon, the stars).  Methodologically, I hope to investigate the extent to which folk song materials--still central in the reconstruction of Finnish and Baltic mythologies but largely rejected in the field of Old Norse studies--can serve as useful tools in reconstructing ancient myths in the region.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[4]</span><span class="style_3"> Lindow: “The extent to which Finnish/Karelian and Nordic mythologies conform is striking. Both were transmitted in the form of short oral poems in relatively simple verse form (setting aside for a moment skaldic poetry) with varying actors and subject matter. Both characters and plots can be compared: Óðinn and Väinämöinen; Þórr and Ilmarinen; verbal duels; the acquisition of precious objects; seeking women from an out-group; the permanence of death. This paper sets forth and evaluates such points of comparison and sets forth the significant differences. Although I am skeptical about the methodology that posits borrowing to explain similarities, I do find that the comparison rewards exploration in a number of ways.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[5]</span><span class="style_3"> Cole: “In this paper, I will chiefly be examining the potential impact of Christian iconography regarding the Jews in </span><span class="style_5">Snorra Edda</span><span class="style_3">. Following work by Heather O'Donoghue ["What has Baldr to do with Lamech?", </span><span class="style_5">Medium Ævum 72</span><span class="style_3">(2003)] I will also consider resonances from some of the originally Jewish exegetical and magical tradition which had been incorporated into Christian learning by the time Snorri Sturluson was writing.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[6]</span><span class="style_3"> Hermann: “This paper is about memory in the medieval period and about how memory had an impact on the literature written in that period. The paper will deal with memory in the mythology created by the texts as well as with memory as a medium for transmission of pagan myths.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[7]</span><span class="style_3"> Heslop: “It is characteristic of the transmission of Old Norse myth and heroic legend that the narratives do not appear ‘as such’, but rather within a frame, for example the ekphrastic framing of the so-called shield poems, the omnipresent framing by various kinds of borders in the visual sources, and the explanatory frames for the poems provided in the Poetic Edda. In this talk, I will compare how narratives are framed in sources from a variety of different points in time and space – possible examples include </span><span class="style_5">Beowulf</span><span class="style_3">, the Rök runestone, Gotlandic picture stones, Swedish runestones, and the </span><span class="style_5">Prose</span><span class="style_3"> and </span><span class="style_5">Poetic Edda</span><span class="style_3"> – and ask questions such as: what are the normative and formative functions of such narratives? How are processes of transmission staged in visual and verbal narrative? What is the ontological status of the texts and objects that transmit mythic and heroic narrative? What happens when they are received by hearers, readers and viewers?” </span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[8]</span><span class="style_3"> Glauser: “This paper deals with some of the well-known Old Norse narratives, which are generally interpreted as manifestations of the myth of the intoxicating drink. In contrast to the majority of previous scholarship (Renate Doht, Peter Buchholz, Svava Jakobsdóttir, Jón Hnefill Aðalsteinsson, Heimir Pálsson and others), my presentation will not so much focus on the often-discussed question of a precise definition of the functions of these narratives as mead of sovereignty and /or mead of poetry. The main interest will rather be on some major aspects the specific literary and visual forms in which these narratives were mediated and transmitted.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[9]</span><span class="style_3"> Kaplan: “If we accept, as many do, that the shadowy author of </span><span class="style_5">Vǫlsa þáttr</span><span class="style_3"> made up this nasty little tale, the question remains: what did he make it out of? This paper approaches </span><span class="style_5">Vǫlsa þáttr</span><span class="style_3"> as a fantasy spun not from half-forgotten heathenism but from folk traditions of the author’s own day.”</span><span class="style_7"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[10]</span><span class="style_3"> Gunnell: “The aim of this lecture is to gather together recurring motifs concerning the peculiarities of the religion of those gods referred to as the Vanir (the reported death of whom might be regarded as a touch premature). A range of Old Norse accounts from different times including </span><span class="style_5">Ynglinga saga, Gunnars þáttr helmings, Gesta Danorum, Hrafnkels saga, Vatnsdæla saga </span><span class="style_3">and more will be used. Many of the aforementioned motifs (commonly concerning ritual activities) tend to be unexplained in the texts but nonetheless have recurring patterns which imply that in their oral traditions, outsiders seem to have seen the religious activities connected with the “Vanir” as having been different in nature to those known outside Sweden. The lecture will consider these differences, and whether they can be considered mere Christian propaganda or perhaps had some distant basis in a “reality” which preceded the arrival of Óðinn, Þórr and the Christian God in Sweden.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[11]</span><span class="style_3"> Jóhanna Katrín: “Although the evidence of the late sagas (e.g., </span><span class="style_5">fornaldarsögur</span><span class="style_3">) has been carefully mined over the years for data reflecting on older Nordic mythological traditions, few scholars have treated the Icelandic </span><span class="style_5">rímur</span><span class="style_3">, in many instances believed to be roughly comparable in age to these extant sagas, with either the same care or the same goals. My paper explores the question whether the </span><span class="style_5">rímur </span><span class="style_3">could be considered a potentially useful source of information about Norse myth.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[12]</span><span class="style_3"> Wellendorf: “What are the idols of the Æsir and what is their nature? In my paper I will seek to confront the teachings of the Bible and the Christian tradition with the idols we meet in Old Norse accounts of myth and ritual in the Northern world.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[13]</span><span class="style_3"> Samplonius: “In recent times, the notion that magic constituted a structural element of Old Nordic Religion has gained much popularity, leading to such interpretations as that one of the women buried at the rich Oseberg Ship funeral had been a </span><span class="style_5">vǫlva</span><span class="style_3">, and, related to it, that a number of staffs from certain 10</span><span class="style_8">th</span><span class="style_3">-century graves had been magic wands. The paper discusses whether the sources at our disposal justify any such conclusion.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[14]</span><span class="style_3"> Zachrisson: “The winged man from Uppåkra, an object that can be placed to the late 8</span><span class="style_8">th</span><span class="style_3"> century, shows a winged man with drops of blood on his left hand/wing. It illustrates perfectly Völund as described in the 13</span><span class="style_8">th</span><span class="style_3">-c. </span><span class="style_5">Þiðriks saga af Bern</span><span class="style_3">. The context for the object - the cult house in Uppåkra - is situated in the South Scandinavian region, and marks one of its nodal points. The time-span c. 750 to 1200 and the opinions on </span><span class="style_5">Þiðriks saga</span><span class="style_3">, as well as the settings in the written texts on Völund (Zealand in </span><span class="style_5">Þiðriks saga </span><span class="style_3">and Svithiod in </span><span class="style_5">Völundarkviða</span><span class="style_3">), are the starting points for my discussion of this interesting comparison.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[15]</span><span class="style_3"> Puett: “This paper will discuss the comparative implications of Old Norse mythology, with a particular focus on China”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[16]</span><span class="style_3"> Nagy: “Traditions about the serpentine element in Ragnar Loðbrók’s heroic biography have been discussed in relation to the episode about the rise and fall of Haftvad’s worm told in the Persian </span><span class="style_5">Shahnameh</span><span class="style_3">. There are, however, analogs in ancient Greek and medieval Irish literature as well, pointing, I will argue, to an underlying Indo-European mythological pattern.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[17]</span><span class="style_3"> Witzel: “A variant of the Old Norse myth of Ymir is found in the oldest Indian text, the </span><span class="style_5">Rgveda</span><span class="style_3">, pointing to a common Indo-European origin. Some other Indo-European speaking peoples have minor, related versions. However, the myth is also found in Old (southern) Chinese myth, and beyond. Questions of origins and local variations will be addressed.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[18]</span><span class="style_3"> Guðrún: “The eddic poem </span><span class="style_5">Grímnismál</span><span class="style_3"> enjoyed a special place in learned writings about myth and skaldic poetry in the thirteenth century. The complete text of the poem is preserved in the two main manuscripts of the eddic poetry, the Codex Regius and the A manuscript, though not in the same sequence nor do the manuscripts carry the exact same text, and individual stanzas are furthermore cited in </span><span class="style_5">Snorra Edda</span><span class="style_3"> (half of the poem), Óláfr Þórðarson‘s</span><span class="style_5">Third Grammatical Treatise</span><span class="style_3"> and in </span><span class="style_5">Litla Skálda</span><span class="style_3">. One of the question underpinning the paper is why this mythological poem played such an important role in learned treatises and cosmological imagery in the thirteenth century. The answer gives an insight into the workings of the textual culture at the time.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[19]</span><span class="style_3"> Bäckvall: “By now, it is hardly controversial to point out that much interesting information about </span><span class="style_5">Edda</span><span class="style_3">, its contents and reception can be gleaned from the Uppsala manuscript of the work. All manuscripts are different, and some are more different than others. In this paper, I will present some instances of how the Uppsala </span><span class="style_5">Edda </span><span class="style_3">differs from the other Edda manuscripts when it comes to the mythological content matter in (primarily) </span><span class="style_5">Gylfaginning</span><span class="style_3">. To put it in another way, I will discuss how our modern ideas of Norse mythology might have been different if this</span><span class="style_5">Edda</span><span class="style_3"> manuscript were the only surviving one.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[20]</span><span class="style_3"> Lyle: “An unexpected parallel has emerged between the Baldr narrative and the narrative of Iraj in the Persian</span><span class="style_5">Shahnameh</span><span class="style_3">, and comparison between them may help to throw light on both as expressions of an Indo-European mythic theme.  In both cases, an innocent and defenceless figure is murdered by a pair, one planning and one acting, and in both cases there is a kinship barrier to immediate revenge, and the murdered man/god is eventually avenged by a hero who was not yet born at the time of the murder.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[21]</span><span class="style_3"> Sundqvist: “In ecclesiastical Latin sources referring to pre-Christian Northern Europe we sometimes meet descriptions of cultic trees/groves and sacrificial wells situated close to temples. Are these descriptions built on a</span><span class="style_5">topos</span><span class="style_3"> taken from mythic traditions or do they reflect a real cosmic symbolism (or a common cultural model) at pre-­Christian cultic sites of these areas? By means of other sources, such as Old Norse texts, place-names and archaeological materials, and a comparative method, I will try to answer this question.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[22]</span><span class="style_3"> Patton: “Focusing on the methodological challenges of the intersection between sacred histories and historicity (real trees and their exfoliation in ritual practice and the religious imagination).”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><span class="style_4">[23]</span><span class="style_3"> Rösli: ”The different mythological concepts of </span><span class="style_5">ragna rǫk</span><span class="style_3">, (Poetic Edda) and </span><span class="style_5">ragnarøkr</span><span class="style_3"> (Prose Edda) have often been interpreted as some sort of fixed ending of the eddic world, followed by a new and independently created world joining a cyclical system of cosmogonies. In this paper I would like to rethink the well-known cyclical structure of these two concepts. I will argue, based on the textual narratives, for a new view on the end of the world and its reshaped and transformed versions.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[24]</span><span class="style_3"> Nordvig: “There is hardly any culture on Earth that has flourished in close proximity to very active volcanoes without producing a rich mythology about them (e.g.,  Hawai'i, Mesoamerica, Rome). In Iceland, there are very few early stories of volcanism. Current scholarship attributes this to a special Icelandic way of dealing with the coarse, subarctic environment of the island (Þórr Þórðarson, “Perception of Volcanic Eruptions in Iceland” [2010]), but this contradicts everything that is known about the way humans linguistically process their physical surroundings when faced with disasters and natural processes (Barber &amp; Barber, </span><span class="style_5">When They Severed Earth from Sky </span><span class="style_3">[2004]; Cashman &amp; Cronin, "Welcoming a Monster to the World: Myths, Oral Tradition, and Modern Societal Response to Volcanic Disasters" [2008]). In my talk I will present some examples of where we can find such conceptualizations of volcanism in Old Norse mythology.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[25]</span><span class="style_3"> Abram: “This paper proposes that the Old Norse myth of </span><span class="style_5">Ragnarök</span><span class="style_3"> illuminates the apocalyptic experience of catastrophic global climate change that we are currently struggling to come to terms with; and our viewpoint at the end of the world (of one world, our world, at least) can provide an important perspective for understanding the events described in </span><span class="style_5">Völuspá</span><span class="style_3">. The crisis at the heart of </span><span class="style_5">Ragnarök</span><span class="style_3"> is an ecological, and ironical, one: it results from the gods’ apparent success in mastering the physical world.”</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">[26]</span><span class="style_3"> Price: “There is now general agreement among geoscientists that in the year AD 536, and for varying lengths of time thereafter, several parts of the world experienced a prolonged solar darkness. This took the form of a loosely-termed ‘dust veil’ blocking the sun’s warmth from reaching the earth, traceable in numerous environmental proxies and probably resulting from a massive volcanic eruption in Central America. Numerous textual sources from the period independently describe what was clearly a natural disaster of some magnitude, with a range of catastrophic effects including crop failure, famine and civil strife. In this paper, building on work by the author and other archaeologists including especially Bo Gräslund, the socially transformative impact of the ‘dust veil’ on the late Iron Age cultures of Scandinavia is explored. In particular, attention is devoted to its possible geomythological legacy in the Old Norse stories of the Fimbulwinter, the prelude to the </span><span class="style_5">Ragnarök</span><span class="style_3">, and in related mythic traditions.”</span></p>
</div>
</div>
</div>
<div class="style_SkipStroke_2">
<div class="text-content graphic_textbox_layout_style_default_External_645_92">
<div class="graphic_textbox_layout_style_default"></div>
</div>
</div></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2013: Upside Down &amp; Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138081" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><h3 style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2">Saturday, April 13, 2013</span></h3>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"></span></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"><strong><span class="style_2">Thompson Room, Barker Center<br /><span class="style_2">Harvard University<br /><span class="style_2">12 Quincy Street, Cambridge MA</span></span></span></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"><strong><span class="style_2">performances * papers * discussions * refreshments<br /></span></strong></p>
<p style="text-align:center" class="paragraph_style_2"><strong><span class="style_2"></span><span class="style_2">free and open to the public</span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_2"><span class="style_2"></span></span><span class="style_2"><strong>Sponsored by:</strong> the Office of the Provost, the Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology, the David Rockefeller Center for Latin American Studies, </span><span class="style_2">the Committee on Dramatics, the Mahindra Humanities Center, the Department of Music, </span><span class="style_2">and the Department of Anthropology at Tufts University</span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">Schedule:</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">9:15 am – Coffee &amp; Welcome:</span><span class="style_2"> Deborah Foster &amp; David Guss<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">9:30 - 10:45 am - PERFORMANCE, PILGRIMAGE &amp; TRANSGRESSION</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Panagiotis Roilos (Harvard), “Festive Byzantines: Holy Days and Profane Rituals in the Greek Middle Ages”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Brenna McDuffie (Harvard), “Performance and Pilgrimage: Performative Displays of Faith at the Kumbh Mela”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Bruce Owens (Wheaton),  “Transgressing Transgression: Inappropriately Behaving at </span><span class="style_2">Bu</span><span class="style_2">ṃ</span><span class="style_2">g</span><span class="style_2">a</span><span class="style_2">y</span><span class="style_2">āḥ</span><span class="style_2"> in the </span><span class="style_2">Kathmandu Valley”</span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">        (read by William F. Fisher, Clark University)<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Michael Witzel (Harvard),  “Two Nepalese Carnivals”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"> </p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2"></span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">10:45 - 11:00 am - COFFEE BREAK</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">11:00 - 12:00 pm - FESTIVE IDENTITIES FOR A HYBRID WORLD</span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Maria Cristina Vlassidis Burgoa (Harvard), “</span><span class="style_2">Santos y Locas: </span><span class="style_2">The African Spirits of Loiza Aldea”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Grete Viddal (Harvard),  “Vodú Chic: Haitians and the Folkloric Imaginary in Socialist Cuba”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Kera Washington (Tufts)  “Adaptation and Identity: Haitian Vodou in Folkloric Performance”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong>12:00 - 1:00 pm - LUNCH</strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"> </p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">1:00 - 2:00 pm - KEYNOTE</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">introduction by Doris Sommer (Harvard)<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:60px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Diana Taylor (NYU)<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:60px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">“Saving the ‘Live’: Performance and Intangible Cultural Heritage”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:60px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"><strong></strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"><strong>2:00 - 2:15 pm - COFFEE BREAK</strong><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2"></span><strong><span class="style_2">2:15 - 3:15 pm - NEIGHBORHOOD SAINTS</span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Augusto  Ferraiuolo (BU),  “Orthodoxy and Orthopraxy: Religious Festive Practice in Boston’s North End”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Henry Cataldo (Mass Art),  “Boston’s North End Religious Feasts: Songs, Cries, and Prayers”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Kay Turner (NYU),  “Saints Alive in Brooklyn: Gender and Performance in Traditional Italian-American </span><span class="style_2">Feste</span><span class="style_2">”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2"></span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2"></span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">3:15 - 4:30 pm - FESTIVALS FOR A SECULAR SOCIETY</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Reebee Garafalo  (UMass Boston), “HONK!: The New Ground Game of Musical Activism”<br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Erminio Pinque (RISD, BIG NAZO LAB),  “Transformative Creature Invasions &amp; Festival Jump-Starting” <br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Joy Fairfield (Stanford), “‘Burning Man was Better Next Year’: Performing Utopian Nostalgia at a Post-Modern </span><span class="style_2">Secular Festival”</span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">Charles Keil  (SUNY/Buffalo),  “Peace &amp; Joy Unlimited: Returning the Festive to Everyday Life”</span><span> </span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2"></span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2"></span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"><strong><span class="style_2">4:30 - PERFORMANCE</span></strong><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style"></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style"><span class="style_2">BIG NAZO</span><span class="style_2"> Intergalactic Creature Invasion Party</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

								<div class="region region-footer-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1389386751" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389386751"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389386751' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p><span style="font-size:medium"><strong>FOLKLORE &amp; MYTHOLOGY</strong></span><br />Barker Center, 12 Quincy Street<br />Cambridge, MA  02138<br />617-495-4788</p></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>								<div class="region region-footer-third"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><section id="block-boxes-1389388220" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html with-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389388220"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
      <h2 class="block-title">Last Updated:</h2>
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389388220' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>
	August 09, 2017
</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1389395993" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389395993"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-383751" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p align="center">Folklore and Mythology Symposium<br /><br />Friday, April 3, 2015<br />Thompson Room Barker Center</p>
<p align="center"></p>
<p><strong>9:30    Coffee and Pastries</strong></p>
<p><strong>9:45    Welcome and Introduction </strong></p>
<p><strong>10:00  Panel I:</strong> <strong>On-line Communities</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Will Harrington:  "The Hunt for Satoshi Nakamoto: is Bitcoin's founder Santa Claus?"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Maggie Vo: "Online Collaborative Storytelling: Liberation through Anonymity and Global Community"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Kareli Osorio: "U.S./U.K. Relations, A Revolution: Gender and Its Role(s) in Male Same-Sex Relationships in Hetalia Fanfiction"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Natalie Chew: “Ace Online: The Asexual Virtual Community”</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Monica Marion: "'Still Boy Play': An Analysis of Gender Inequality in ESports"</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>11:15  Coffee Break</strong></p>
<p><strong>11:30 Panel II:</strong> <strong>Globalization and Expressive Culture</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Leah Lowthorp: "Performing Politics: UNESCO Intangible Cultural Heritage in India"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Heike Currie: “West African Dance across the Waters and Web”</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Frank Korom:  "Global Citizens, Local Bards: Bengali Responses to Globalization."</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Khytie Brown: "‘Drilling the Bands’ from ‘Yaad’ to Abroad”:  Revival Zion, Social Media and Translocalism"</p>
<p><strong>12:45 Lunch</strong></p>
<p><strong>1:45    Keynote: Trevor Blank</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">"The World at Our Fingertips: Folklore, Digital Culture, and the Pursuit of Meaning in Contemporary Vernacular Discourse."</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>2:45    Coffee Break</strong></p>
<p><strong>3:00    Panel III:</strong> <strong>Digital Preservation and Cultural Reproduction</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">David Elmer: “The Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature in the Digital Age.”</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Felicity Lufkin: "American Quilts in a Globalized Context: The Smithsonian Quilt Controversy"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Finnian Gerrety: "Digital Guru: the Embodied Archive, Digitization, and Authenticity in the Transmission of Vedic Knowledge"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Sara Berliner: "Peekaboo Barn and the Commercialization of Culture"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"> </p>
<p><strong>4:15    Panel IV:</strong> <strong>Netlore/Techlore</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Anthony Buccitelli: "The Embodied Performance of Folklore (enhanced): Tradition Memory, Poetic Sharing, and Digital Technology"</p>
<p style="padding-left:30px"> Kerey Luis: “We Are All Moon Moon: Negotiating Identity, and Insider/Outsider Status, Through Fanlore in Online Communities”               </p>
<p style="padding-left:30px">Hannah Sarvasy: "The Woman Who Gave Birth to a Snake: Twenty-First Century Rumor and Reality in a New Guinea Community"</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>5:30</strong>    <strong>STORYTELLING PERFORMANCE BY REBECCA NESSON</strong></p>
<p></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>
		  </header>
      <!--header regions end-->
		
				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">

href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/people/taxonomy/term/13466" ><span>Staff</span></a></li><li class="menu-7192 menu-path-node-138271   even  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentrators" ><span>Concentrators</span></a></li><li class="menu-7193 menu-path-node-138276   odd   last "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/alumni"  title=""><span>Alumni</span></a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-6802 menuparent  menu-path-node-131491   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events"  title=""><span>Calendar & Events</span></a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-6825 menu-path-calendar  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar"  title=""><span>Current Calendar</span></a></li><li class="menu-7178 menu-path-node-137976   even   last "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  title=""><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a></li></ul></li><li class="menu-6804 menu-path-node-131501   even  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/resources" ><span>Resources</span></a></li><li class="menu-6814 menu-path-node-131546   odd   last "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact-0"  title=""><span>Contact</span></a></li></ul>

  </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      About                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-131471" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p style="text-align:center"><strong><span style="font-family:'times new roman', times; font-size:large">An Introduction to the Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</span></strong></p>
<p>The concentration in Folklore and Mythology is a liberal education in itself, and although most graduates of the program go on to successful careers in medicine, law, business, journalism, and other pursuits, an unusually large number of our alumni and alumnae teach and conduct research in a variety of academic departments. This concentration focuses on the study of society, past or present, through its cultural documents and artifacts, and uses a variety of methodologies drawn from the humanities and social sciences. To concentrate on a society’s folklore and mythology (on sub-national as well as national levels) is to understand its traditional self-definition through its epics, ballads, folktales, legends, beliefs, and other cultural phenomena, including music, song, and dance, and studying a group’s folklore shows how it identifies itself in relation to other groups.</p>
<p>Concentrators conduct independent research on folklore and mythology in a variety of cultures including, for example, African, American, Chinese, Celtic, English, Greek, German, Japanese, Sanskrit &amp; Indian Studies, Scandinavian, and Slavic. Founded in 1967 and the oldest undergraduate degree program in the field in this country, Folklore and Mythology at Harvard has produced many distinguished graduates. Students often form mutually supportive groups; student-faculty contact is by tradition — and structure — very close; and collegiality within the program is highly valued.</p>
<p>Three central courses of the Concentration (Culture and Belief 16, formerly Folklore and Mythology 100; 97; and 98a) provide an introduction to the field of folkloristics, general knowledge of the theories and methods of the field, as well as a survey of ethnographic field methods and ethnological methodology. Three more courses from among the Folklore and Mythology offerings (e.g., Witchcraft, Swahili Women Storytellers, African Folklore in the New World, Legend, Myth, Dance as a Site of Cultural and Personal Meaning, The Mythic Imagination) round out the core folklore courses.</p>
<p>In addition to this central core, each concentrator selects a Special Field. Roughly speaking, these fields fall into those that are grounded in a particular culture or language (such as African, Celtic, Classics, English and American, German, Near Eastern, Sanskrit and Indian Studies) and those that are not (such as Anthropology, Linguistics, Psychology, Sociology, Ethnomusicology, Performance). Concentrators gain in-depth knowledge of the Special Field by taking at least five half-courses in it. The second half of the Junior tutorial (98b) investigates areas for research at the intersection of the Special Field and folklore proper. The senior tutorial is devoted to the honors thesis required of all concentrators.</p>
<p>The dual structure of the Concentration, together with the unique position of folklore studies between the humanities and the social sciences, offers students an insurance policy against parochialism, while at the same time guaranteeing a deep and certain grasp of a traditional discipline. The original faculty legislation founding the program charged that candidates be prepared to do graduate work in the departments represented by their Special Field, as well as in Folklore and Mythology. In fact, our graduates have, over the years, exercised not only those alternatives, but have, like most graduates of the College, gone on to careers in law, business, medicine, and a variety of other professions, including journalism and film.</p>
<p>No special background is required for any Folklore and Mythology course, but good general preparation in languages, literature, history, and expository writing will be advantageous. Our Concentration strongly recommends proficiency in a language other than English, equivalent to that acquired by two years of college study. Generally, languages are very important to advanced work in folklore and in the Special Fields, and prospective concentrators are urged to look to language preparation in high school and from the beginning of their freshman year. In some of our Special Fields, language study may be counted toward concentration.</p>
<p>All potential concentrators should make an appointment with the Head Tutor to discuss Special Field options and suggested courses, by the first Friday in April.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390598396' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168491" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/three-bears2.jpg?m=1492187822">three-bears2.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/three-bears2.jpg?m=1499734734&amp;itok=6o3cYGhN" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-46766"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about"  class="active-trail active active"><span>About</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-189656"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/brief-history-folklore-and-mythology-harvard" ><span>A Brief History of Folklore and Mythology at Harvard</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-48531"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/warren-house" ><span>Warren House</span></a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48536"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/art-credits-site" ><span>Art Credits for SIte</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-131481 header-left header-main content-top footer-left footer-right content-top-slideshow-enabled">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>
		  </header>
      <!--header regions end-->
		
				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-900 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><span>HOME</span></a></li><li class="menu-6799 menuparent  menu-path-node-131471   even  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about" ><span>About</span></a><span class="open-submenu"></span><ul><li class="menu-7191 menu-path-node-131471  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about" ><span>Intro to Folklore & Mythology</span></a></li><li   </nav></div>		  <!--main menu region end-->
		
    
		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Academics                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-131481" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Please see the links at left for Folklore &amp; Mythology courses, cross-listings, and the requirements for the concentration and the secondary field.</p>
<p>If you are interested in talking to us about concentrating in F&amp;M, you may schedule an appointment with Stephen Mitchell (<a href="mailto:samitch@fas.harvard.edu">samitch@fas.harvard.edu</a>).  Please email <a href="mailto:hhutchis@fas.harvard.edu">hhutchis@fas.harvard.edu</a> to arrange an appointment.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390602455" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390602455"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390602455' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-169006" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/red-riding-hood-2.jpg?m=1492209389">red-riding-hood-2.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/red-riding-hood-2.jpg?m=1499777673&amp;itok=4-8bTL5w" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-46866"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Academics</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-46871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/advising-0" ><span>Advising</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-47651"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics/courses" ><span>Courses</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-48431"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" ><span>Concentration Requirements</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48486"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field" ><span>Secondary Field</span></a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48526"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/swapna-dev-memorial-book-prize" ><span>The Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-131481 header-left header-main content-top footer-left footer-right content-top-slideshow-enabled">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>
		  </header>
