                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Cross-Listed Courses                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138156" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline"></span>01/14/2016: </strong>cross-listings updated for Spring 2016.</p>
<p></p>
<p><strong><span style="text-decoration:underline"><a href="https://portal.my.harvard.edu">Harvard Course Search page.</a></span></strong></p>
<p><strong>[Love In A Dead Language: Classical Indian Literature and Its Theorists]<br /></strong>AESTHINT 30<br />Parimal G. Patil<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>123914</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An exploration of love in five genres of classical South Asian literature$epic history, story literature, plays, poetic miniatures, and court poetry. We will pay particular attention to the nature of literary genres and practices and how they were theorized by South Asian intellectuals. Especially relevant are theories of poetic language, aestheticized emotion (especially love), and literary ornamentation.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engage substantially with Study of the Past.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Ancient Fictions: The Ancient Novel in Context<br /></strong>AESTHINT 33<br />David Elmer<br />2015 Fall<br />Mon/Wed, 11:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14909  <strong>Course ID: </strong>124912</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>The novel is often thought of as a distinctively modern form, but Greco-Roman antiquity had its own version. Fictional prose narratives about adventure and romance in exotic lands were immensely popular in antiquity. We will explore this tradition by reading the five surviving Greek novels, the <em>Golden Ass</em> of the Roman Apuleius, and selected other texts, along with works by contemporary theorists and critics. Topics include: definitions of the "novel"; ancient representations of desire; gender and class politics; relationships between secular and religious narratives.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engage substantially with Study of the Past.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Buddhism and Japanese Culture<br /></strong>AESTHINT 36<br />Ryuichi Abe<br />2016 Spring<br />Tues/Thurs, 02:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>13207  <strong>Course ID: </strong>123913</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course is designed to enable students to analyze a wide range of Japanese cultural creations_including the traditional Noh theater, modern Japanese paintings, and contemporary anime_by illustrating the influence of Buddhism both on their forms and at their depths. The first part of the course is a study of major Buddhist philosophy and its impact on Japanese literature. The second part observes Buddhist ritual practices and their significance for Japanese performing arts. The last part traces the development of Japanese Buddhist art, and considers the influence of Buddhism on diverse contemporary popular Japanese art media.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Afro-Latin America: History and Culture<br /></strong>AFRAMER 124Y<br />Alejandro de la Fuente, Doris Sommer<br />2016 Spring<br />Tuesday, 01:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14785  <strong>Course ID: </strong>159570</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course explores how African cultural expressions influenced colonial societies and later national cultures in Latin America. How did peoples of African descent shape the formation of Latin American national cultures in areas such as literature, religion, visual arts, music, dance, and cinema? Some scholars have debated whether African religious, musical, medical and communitarian practices were reproduced in the New World or whether they were creolized through fusion with other (European and indigenous) practices. Others have sought to explain how African cultural practices (music, religion, dances) that were derided as primitive and uncivilized in the early twentieth century became "nationalized" and transformed into key expressions of national cultures in many Latin American countries. What are the implications of this process for those cultural forms and their practitioners? How do they impact, if at all, other areas of social life?  We explore these questions through historical and literary texts, films, visual arts, and recordings.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong> [African Religions]<br /></strong>AFRAMER 187<br />Jacob Olupona<br />Likely to be offered in 2016 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>123438</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course is a basic introduction to the history and phenomenology of traditional religions of the African peoples. Using diverse methodological and theoretical approaches, the course will explore various forms of experiences and practices that provide a deep understanding and appreciation of the sacred meaning of African existence: myth, ritual arts, and symbols selected from West, East, Central, and Southern Africa.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3690.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Introduction to Mesopotamian Religion]<br /></strong>ANE 102<br />Piotr Steinkeller<br />Likely to be offered in 2018 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>114298</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>A survey of the history and major concerns of ancient Mesopotamian religion from prehistoric times down to the reign of Alexander the Great. Among the topics treated are the key figures of the Sumero-Babylonian pantheon, the major mythological compositions (read in translation), personal religion, cosmogonies and theogonies, magic and divination, Mesopotamian temples, and cult and ritual. The course makes rich use of ancient iconography.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3661.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Maya Narratives: Gods, Lords, and Courts]<br /></strong>ANTHRO 1158<br />Likely to be offered in 2016 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>128062</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course explores the continuing investigation of Classic Maya texts and images, and how new decipherments have changed our understanding of the ancient Maya world. The Classic Maya are the only Pre-Columbian civilization with a substantial corpus of inscriptions produced well before any contact with the Old World. Maya written and visual narratives reveal details of history and myth, life at the courts of lords and nobles, and religion and worldview. Their testimonies are often striking, unique, and hard to understand, but they are not mediated by non-indigenous interpreters and open a window into a world long gone.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Armenian Magical Texts]<br /></strong>ARMEN 120<br />James Russell<br />Likely to be offered in 2018 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>124288</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Armenian magical texts include codices, scrolls, and separately-printed saints' lives used for good or ill, containing magic squares and symbols, the latter mostly deriving from Islamic magic. The course will consider literary sources of magic texts (e.g., the prayer Havatov khostovanim, the meditations of Narek), parallel traditions (esp. Christian Ethiopia), and the consideration of the paintings in Armenian magical manuscripts from the standpoint of the genre of Outsider Art.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 2200.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[The Hero of Irish Myth and Saga]<br /></strong>CELTIC 101<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>122419</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>A study of the ways in which the hero is represented in early Irish sources, especially in the saga literature. The texts reflect the ideology and concerns of a society which had been converted to Christianity, but continued to draw on its Indo-European and Celtic heritage. The biographies of the Ulster hero, Cú Chulainn, of his divine father, Lug, and of certain king-heroes are studied in depth. The wisdom literature, and archaeological and historical evidence will be taken into account.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Folklore of Gaelic Ireland<br /></strong>CELTIC 105<br />Natasha Sumner<br />2016 Spring<br />Mon/Wed, 02:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15731  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160495</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An introduction to the oral traditions of Gaelic Ireland, including tales and song. The process of collecting is explored, and various folkloristic theories and approaches applied in order to gain a deeper understanding of the material. No knowledge of Irish Gaelic required.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Weekly discussion section to be arranged.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[The Folklore of Gaelic Scotland]<br /></strong>CELTIC 106<br />Natasha Sumner<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>127369</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An introduction to the oral traditions of Gaelic Scotland and Nova Scotia, including tales and song. The process of collecting is explored, and various folkloristic theories and approaches applied in order to gain a deeper understanding of the material. No knowledge of Scottish Gaelic required.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Finn: The Great Gaelic Hero<br /></strong>CELTIC 109<br />Natasha Sumner<br />2015 Fall<br />Mon/Wed, 11:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15723  <strong>Course ID: </strong>127630</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course explores the lengthy and wildly popular Irish and Scottish Gaelic tradition surrounding the hero, Finn mac Cumaill (a.k.a. 'Finn MacCool' or 'Fionn mac Cumhaill'). Finn is variously portrayed as a hunter-warrior-seer and is the leader of the intrepid fíana war band. We survey this Fenian literature as it is presented to us by medieval and early modern Gaelic manuscript tradition. We also engage with the rich modern Fenian folklore of Ireland, Scotland, and Nova Scotia. This includes the study of important texts such as Acallam na Senórach ‘The Dialogue of the Ancients’ and Tóraigheacht Dhiarmada agus Ghráinne ‘The Pursuit of Diarmaid and Gráinne’. Additionally, we consider the international impact of the Fenian tradition by examining James Macpherson's infamous, eighteenth-century, English-language adaptations and the ensuing Ossian controversy.  All Gaelic texts are read in English translation.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[The Gaelic World: 1100 - 1700]<br /></strong>CELTIC 118<br />Natasha Sumner<br />Likely to be offered in 2016 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>127370</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An introduction to the history and culture of Gaelic Scotland and Ireland, with particular attention to contemporary sources, including Gaelic literary sources. All readings in English translation.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Celtic Mythology]<br /></strong>CELTIC 137<br />Likely to be offered in 2016 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>111202</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>A survey of the sources for the study of Celtic mythology, with special attention to selected texts from early Ireland and Wales. All texts are read in English translation.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Táin<br /></strong>CELTIC 184<br />Tomas O Cathasaigh<br />2016 Spring<br />Mon/Wed/Fri, 01:00pm - 01:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15730  <strong>Course ID: </strong>111284</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>A study of the exuberant Irish prose epic <em>Táin Bó Cúailnge</em> (`Cattle-Raid of Cooley'). Text read in English translation.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> The Friday meeting time is occasional.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Folklore in the Modern Chinese Cultural Imagination<br /></strong>CHNSLIT 129<br />Max Bohnenkamp<br />2015 Fall<br />Tuesday, 01:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16774  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160438</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This seminar course examines the role of folklore and notions of cultural authenticity in the construction of the modern Chinese nation. With the launching of the “Folklore Studies Movement” in the 1910s, Chinese intellectuals discovered new sources for defining their cultural identity in the songs, legends and customs of the countryside. Ever since then, different representations of folk culture have been enlisted to define modern life in China, from the appropriation of folklore to create a new literature and the critical study of Chinese society through the lens of folk narratives and beliefs, to the adaptation of folk culture for disseminating revolutionary politics. We will look at folklore itself, sources on the study of folk culture, and modern works of poetry, fiction, film and music to examine the influence of ideas about cultural authenticity on literature, social science and politics in China over the span of the last century.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Images of Greek Myths in Classical Antiquity<br /></strong>CLASARCH 149<br />Adrian Staehli<br />2015 Fall<br />Thursday, 04:00pm - 05:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>18104  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160357  <br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>30  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This seminar explores the visual "language" of the representation of Greek myths in various media—such as painted vases, sculpture, mosaics, wall paintings, and sarcophagi—from its emergence in Archaic Greece through the Hellenistic and Roman periods to Late Antiquity.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Magicians, Healing Gods, and Holy Men<br /></strong>CLS-STDY 113<br />Gil Renberg<br />2015 Fall<br />Mon/Wed, 01:00pm - 01:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16137  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160535</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course will examine magic, divination, and other unconventional religious phenomena in the Greco-Roman world by focusing on extraordinary practices and practitioners. The topics to be explored include soliciting curative dreams from the gods; employing protective magic to ward off disease and other dangerous forces; using aggressive forms of magic to ensnare the object of one’s sexual desires or harm one’s opponents; the rise of “holy men” believed to have supernatural powers; and attempting to foresee the future through astrology or various forms of divination. The sources for these phenomena, most of which are strikingly different from those typically encountered when studying the ancient world, provide fresh perspectives.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Storytelling and Deceptive Narration at Rome and Beyond<br /></strong>CLS-STDY 141<br />Brigitte Libby<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 01:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15793  <strong>Course ID: </strong>159812</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>How do we make others believe us when we stretch the truth? This course is both a survey of ancient Roman literature and an introduction to the classic tools of storytelling and deception that we still encounter today. We will study how ancient authors manipulate our perception of the stories they tell and see how these techniques recur in modern examples. Topics include historical legend, love poetry, the courtroom strategy of Cicero, political propaganda in epic poetry, Aesopic fables, ghost stories, and the account of a man transformed into a donkey. We end with several modern short stories. Readings are in English.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Ancient Greek Hero<br /></strong>CULTBLF 22<br />Gregory Nagy<br />2015 Fall<br />Mon/Wed, 12:00pm - 12:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>11966  <strong>Course ID: </strong>113501</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course takes a close look at the human condition, as viewed through the lens of classical Greek civilization (and some modern comparanda).The readings, all in English translation, are the Homeric Iliad and Odyssey, seven tragedies (Aeschylus' Oresteia Trilogy, Sophocles' two Oedipus dramas, and Euripides' Hippolytus and The Bacchic Women), and two dialogues of Plato (the Apology and the Phaedo, both centering on the last days of Socrates); also, selections from the dialogue On Heroes by an eminent thinker in the "second sophistic" movement, Philostratus.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engage substantially with Study of the Past.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Classical Mythology<br /></strong>CULTBLF 35<br />Brigitte Libby<br />2016 Spring<br />Tues/Thurs, 11:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14844  <strong>Course ID: </strong>126004</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Incest and parricide, cannibalism and self-blinding: classical mythology has fascinated artists, writers, and thinkers throughout western civilization, and this course will serve as an introduction to this strange and brilliant world. We will move from the very first works of Greek literature through to the classic Greek tragedies and the Roman tales in Ovid's Metamorphoses. Along the way, we will confront the question of what "mythology" is and how it works, and we will discuss how these traditional stories changed over time to fit different cultural circumstances. We will also consider ancient rationalizations of myth, the relationship of myth and politics, and the reception of classical myth in the modern world.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> This course fulfills the requirement that one of the eight General Education courses also engage substantially with Study of the Past.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Old English: Beowulf and its Contexts<br /></strong>ENGLISH 103G<br />Joey McMullen<br />2016 Spring<br />Tues/Thurs, 11:30am - 12:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14483  <strong>Course ID: </strong>130249</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>We will translate some of the most fascinating sections of Beowulf—from monster-slaying and heroic feats to pagan burials and betrayals—in order to learn what makes it an exceptional poem. We will also combine language study with literary criticism to consider different aspects of Beowulf each week: the artistry of poetic language, the use of Germanic legend, or the sophistication of the meter, for example.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Fulfills the College language requirement and the English Department's Foreign Literature requirement.</p>
<p><strong>Recommended Prep:</strong> Honors grade in English 102g or the equivalent.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Art of Storytelling<br /></strong>FRSEMR 32V<br />Deborah Foster<br />2016 Spring<br /><strong>Location:</strong> <span style="color:#ff0000">Warren House, Room 102</span><br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>13644  <strong>Course ID: </strong>122447</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>People everywhere tell stories to express both the verities and contradictions found in experiences of everyday life. Based on storytelling traditions, a narrator shapes the story to reflect his or her own intentions, making it personally expressive as well as publicly meaningful to a particular audience. This seminar examines the nature of storytelling, its enduring appeal, and its ability to adapt to multiple technologies (print, film, internet). Participants engage in the storytelling process itself.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Dead Cthulhu Waits Dreaming: H.P. Lovecraft and Mythology<br /></strong>FRSEMR 34D<br />James Russell<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16259  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160202<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>H.P. Lovecraft, the American writer of science fiction, horror, and fantasy, created a cosmology, a mythology,  and an alternative vision of life and reality so compelling that over the years some readers have come to believe that his invented Necronomicon is a real book (in the Widener stacks). Like his predecessor, Edgar Allan Poe, Lovecraft lived and died without recognition in his own country: American culture then as now valued practicality and social engagement.  What is it, then, that captivates Lovecraftians? The seminar will explore the invention of personal mythologies, languages, and narratives of counter-realities by Lovecraft and other writers (including Poe, C.G. Jung, Ursula Le Guin, Colin Wilson, and Philip K. Dick) as ways of individuation, and of resistance to conformity, through creative imagination.  </p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Folklore of Gaelic Scotland<br /></strong>FRSEMR 34F<br />Natasha Sumner<br />2015 Fall<br />Monday, 02:30pm - 05:29pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16260  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160204<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course explores the ‘treasure house’ of Gaelic folklore recorded in the Highlands of Scotland since the nineteenth century. The international controversy over Macpherson’s 'Ossian' poems in the 1760s prompted interest in the Scottish Gaelic folklore from which they were adapted. Folklorists have since documented a wealth of orally recorded material, including tales of ancient heroes (e.g. Finn McCool) and beliefs in malevolent fairies, seal-people, dangerous water-horses, the evil eye and second sight. As we explore these fascinating topics, we will take into account international scholarly approaches to folklore. </p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> No knowledge of Scottish Gaelic is required for this course. The seminar will also include 'an end-of-term 'ceilidh", a traditional social gathering often involving song, dance, and/or storytelling.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Comparative Historical Mythology<br /></strong>FRSEMR 36S<br />Michael Witzel<br />2016 Spring<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16522  <strong>Course ID: </strong>109498<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>15  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Deals with an innovative approach to comparative mythology by incorporating an <em>historical </em>approach, not by the commonly assumed archetypes or diffusion. Working backwards from our earliest written sources (Egypt, etc.), successively earlier stages are detected through repeated reconstructions. Recent developments in genetics, archaeology, linguistics support the proposed historical model that tentatively reaches back to the "African Eve." Testing the proposal offers a wide scope for students' participation and research in texts and in the sciences. Open to Freshmen only.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Biopolitics and Vampire Aesthetics, 1716-2016<br /></strong>GERMAN 170<br />Nicole Suetterlin<br />2016 Spring<br />Wed, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15769  <strong>Course ID: </strong>156124</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course traces the infamous bloodsucker's bite-marks through major periods of European literature from the 18th century to the present, exploring how the notion of vampirism is inextricably linked with the emergence of what Michel Foucault has famously called `biopolitics' or 'bio-power'. Since the 18<sup>th</sup> century, institutions such as schools, clinics and prisons have exerted an increasing “hold over life” (Foucault), conditioning the ways in which we think and act. Why does the emergence of these modern institutions coincide precisely with the vampire's first appearance in European literature? Have the arts been defying the biopolitical hold over life by creating a vampiric aesthetics? We pursue these questions by engaging in a dialogue between literature, film, the natural sciences, and critical theory. Readings include canonical authors such as Goethe, Byron, Hoffmann, Baudelaire, Nietzsche, Stoker, Tawada.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> <span>Readings and discussions in English. Open to freshmen with permission of the instructor.</span></p>
<p></p>
<p><strong>Homer: The Odyssey<br /></strong>GREEK 115<br />David Elmer<br />2016 Spring<br />Mon/Wed/Fri, 01:00pm - 01:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14913  <strong>Course ID: </strong>112212</p>
<p><strong>Description:</strong>Reading of substantial selections from the <em>Odyssey</em> with discussion of key themes and interpretive problems. Topics to be addressed include: narrative structure; oral poetics and folklore; self-referentiality; the <em>Odyssey</em> in relation to the <em>Iliad;</em> cultic dimensions.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Greek World Literature: From Homer to Kazantzakis, Cavafy, and Beyond<br /></strong>MODGRK 124<br />Panagiotis Roilos<br />2015 Fall<br />Tuesday, 01:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number:</strong>15037  <strong>Course ID: </strong>112571</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>The course focuses on examples of Greek world literature that had a great influence on authors across geographical and linguistic boundaries. Works and authors to be discussed include the Homeric epics, ancient Greek tragedy, C. P. Cavafy, N. Kazantzakis, G. Seferis, O. Elytis, G. Ritsos.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> All texts will be available in English translation.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Back Roads to Far Places: Literature of Journey and Quest<br /></strong>HDS 2490<br />William A. Graham, Stephanie Paulsell<br />2016 Fall<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>10098  <strong>Course ID: </strong>104279</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course will explore the pervasive themes of journey and quest in world literature with particular attention to their religious dimensions. Through direct encounter with imaginative literary works from a variety of contexts and genres, we will consider the relationship between interior journeys and journeys through an external landscape, home and exile, and the religious and literary dimensions of literature itself. The course will focus on primary texts, with little required reading of secondary materials except in the preparation of a final paper. The lectures will explore important themes as well as supply contextual location for each week's text, discuss issues of genre, style, reception history, and key literary questions and concepts (e.g., myth, legend, epic, the novel, the Doppelgänger, allegories, composite narrative, oral formulaic composition, symbolism, scripture, Bildungsroman, haiku,  classic models). Emphasis throughout will be placed upon careful reading of the texts, which will include Tolkien's <em>Hobbit</em>, <em>Gilgamesh</em>, the Bible, Dante's <em>Inferno</em>, Teresa of Avila's <em>Interior Castle</em>, <em>Life of the Buddha</em>, Hesse's <em>Siddhartha</em>, Basho's <em>Narrow Road to the Deep North</em>, Endo's <em>Deep River</em>, McCarthy's <em>The Road</em>, and others. Jointly offered as Culture and Belief 32.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Indian Religions Through Their Narrative Literatures: The Epics<br /></strong>HDS 3405<br />Anne E. Monius<br />2017 Spring<br />Mon/Wed, 10:00am - 11:00am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>10058  <strong>Course ID: </strong>105033</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An examination of the religious traditions and communities of South Asia through the stories they tell. This semester's focus will be the epics-the Mahabharata and the Ramayana-in their numerous textual, regional, sectarian, and performative tellings.Jointly offered as Religion 1625</p>
<p><strong>Class Notes:</strong> Course has additional section hour to be arranged.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>African Religions<br /></strong>HDS 3690<br />Jacob Olupona<br />2016 Fall<br />Thursday, 04:00pm - 06:00pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>10021  <strong>Course ID: </strong>129478</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course is a basic introduction to the history and phenomenology of traditional religions of the African peoples. Using diverse methodological and theoretical approaches, the course will explore various forms of experiences and practices that provide a deep understanding and appreciation of the sacred meaning of African existence: myth, ritual arts, and symbols selected from West, East, Central, and Southern Africa.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Virgil: Aeneid<br /></strong>LATIN 106B<br />Richard Tarrant<br />2016 Spring<br />Mon/Wed/Fri, 11:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14907  <strong>Course ID: </strong>120309<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>30 </p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Reading and discussion of Virgil's <em>Aeneid,</em> with attention to its place in the epic tradition and its status as a work of Augustan literature.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Japanese Folk Religion: Conference Course]<br /></strong>JAPNHIST 117<br />Helen Hardacre<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>108235</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This conference course is an introduction to the study of Japanese folk religion, popular religious life carried on largely outside the frameworks of Buddhism, Shinto, and other religious institutions. The course aims to interrogate the idea of folk religion and its viability as a field of study within Japanese religions and within contemporary society. In its first half, the course examines the traditional rubrics and topics in the literature on Japanese folk religion. In the second half, the course turns to changes in folk religious life brought about through tourism and the appropriation of folk religious motifs by such contemporary media forms as animé and manga.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Shinto: Conference Course<br /></strong>JAPNHIST 126<br />Helen Hardacre<br />2016 Spring<br />Wednesday, 10:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>12681  <strong>Course ID: </strong>120323</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>An examination of Shinto, emphasizing its concepts of deity (<em>kami</em>), patterns of ritual and festival, shrines as religious and social institutions, political culture and interactions with party politics, and its contribution to contemporary youth culture.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> General knowledge of Japanese history and religion is helpful. Japanese language is not required, but several meetings will be held for students able to use Japanese-language sources. Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3960.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Major Issues in the Study of Japanese Religions<br /></strong>JAPNHIST 214R<br />Helen Hardacre<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 10:00am - 11:59am<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14686  <strong>Course ID: </strong>159553<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>30  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This seminar is primarily for graduate students preparing for research and teaching in Japanese religions.  Because it will have a different focus each time it is offered, students may take it more than once.  The topic for Fall 2015 will be ethnographic studies of Shinto.  Future offerings of the course will focus on such topics as shrine festivals<em> (matsuri)</em>, religion in the Japanese empire, and Japanese new religious movements.  Most readings will be in English, but Japanese-language readings will also be included.</p>
<p><strong>Topic:</strong> Ethnographic Studies of Shinto</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3961.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Literary and Visual Narrative in the Persian Epic Tradition]<br /></strong>PERSIAN 152<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Fall<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>107672</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Both poetry and the art of painting in medieval Persianate cultures developed to a high level of artistic excellence in the context of court patronage. This course examines that development through the epic tradition in medieval Persian poetry and prose including long narratives in heroic, romance, folk and ethical genres. The course considers the affinities and differences between these and epic tales from other traditions as well as their interactions with Persian painting and manuscript illustration. Beginning with the Parthian romance of <em>Vis and Ramin</em> and the heroic epic of <em>Shahnameh</em>, the survey will continue with epic romances of Nizami, prose narratives about folk heroes such as <em>Abu Muslimnameh</em>, and didactic epics by Sa`di and others.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> The course lectures and readings will be in English but there will be a separate section for students with adequate knowledge of Persian to read the relevant texts in Persian.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Dreams and the Dreaming<br /></strong>RELIGION 1012A<br />Kimberley Patton<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14891  <strong>Course ID: </strong>115684</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Considers the dream as initiatory experience, metaphor for aboriginal time, gateway to the other world, venue for the divine guide, healing event, "royal road" to the unconscious, quest or journey, epistemological paradox, or omen of the personal or collective future. Theories of dreaming, the religious history of dream interpretation, and dreams in myth and ritual will be examined cross-culturally, including the theological and spiritual dimensions of human dreaming. Focus during the first semester is on ancient Greece, Judaism, Christianity, and Islam; recent research on American dreams.</p>
<p><strong>Class Notes:</strong> Additional hour to be arranged.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Dreams and the Dreaming<br /></strong>RELIGION 1012B<br />Kimberley Patton<br />2016 Spring<br />Wednesday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14836  <strong>Course ID: </strong>115685</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>A continuation of Dreams and the Dreaming. We will evaluate current research in the psychology and neurobiology of dreams with respect to relevance for the religious and spiritual dimensions of human dreaming. Focus is on Eastern, Native American, and Australian aboriginal traditions.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3315b. This course can be taken either as the second half of a year-long sequence, or as a single-semester, stand-alone course.</p>
<p><strong>Class Notes:</strong> Additional hour to be arranged.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Twins and Twinship in Religion and Myth<br /></strong>RELIGION 1032<br />Kimberley Patton<br />2016 Spring<br />Thursday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14837  <strong>Course ID: </strong>127699<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>20  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This comparative seminar interrogates the meaning of “doubling” a living being, and how this can be religiously, culturally, and mythically expressed. The birth of two children instead of one presents anomaly, in some traditions causing anxiety that can only be ritually resolved, or in others creating opportunity. Twins link worlds that single children cannot, or embody signs, auspicious or suspicious. How are "real" twins related to the divine twins of religion and myth, if they are at all?</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School 3310. Application only at the first class.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Ancient Greek Sanctuaries: Sacred Games<br /></strong>RELIGION 1330<br />Kimberley Patton<br />2015 Fall<br />Thursday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>14843  <strong>Course ID: </strong>159709<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>15  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Why were ancient Greek athletic competitions conducted as religious tradition and ritual observance? What was the relationship of the idealized Greek athlete to the Olympian world of the gods, and the chthonic, local world of the heroes? How were athletics related to political power and cultural memory? Exploring the four classical sanctuaries that were the sites of Panhellenic games (Olympic, Pythian [Delphi], Nemean, and Isthmian [Corinth]), as well as the Panathenaic Games in Athens, this course considers both archeological and literary evidence.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Enrollment limited to 15 with the permission of the instructor, by application at the first course meeting. Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3111.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>The Politics of Storytelling<br /></strong>RELIGION 1920<br />Michael Jackson<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>10683  <strong>Course ID: </strong>109925</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course addresses Hannah Arendt's thesis that storytelling is a critical strategy for bridging the gap between private and public realms. Storytelling is thus understood as a mode of social and political activity that involves a struggle between personal and collective representations of the "truth" and between unofficial and official versions of events. Through the close analysis of storytelling in a variety of situations, we will explore the ways in which the meaning of stories resides not in any ahistorical essence or internal logic, but emerges from the everyday human struggle to strike a balance between domains of experience that are, on the one hand, felt to belong to oneself or one's own kind, and, on the other, felt to be shared by or to belong to others.</p>
<p><strong>Course Notes:</strong> Offered jointly with the Divinity School as 3859.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Old Norse Language, Literature, and Culture: The Viking Legacy<br /></strong>SCAND 160A<br />Stephen Mitchell<br />2015 Fall<br />Wednesday, 12:00pm - 01:59pm<br /><strong>Location: </strong>Warren 102 (FAS)<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>12552  <strong>Course ID: </strong>118050<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Introduction to the language and literary culture of medieval Scandinavia, emphasizing works treating the Viking Age and their valorization of an heroic ideal. In addition to basic language skills, students acquire familiarity with key critical tools of the field. Readings include skaldic poetry, selections from <em>Egils saga</em> and the Vinland sagas, and various runic monuments.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Old Norse Language, Literature, and Culture: Mythology<br /></strong>SCAND 160BR<br />Stephen Mitchell<br />2016 Spring<br />Tuesday, 01:00pm - 02:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>12606  <strong>Course ID: </strong>118051<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Builds on Scandinavian 160a, continuing the language study and cultural survey of the first term, but now considers mythological texts relating to Viking religious life, mainly selections from the prose and poetic Eddas with particular attention to issues of magic and the scholarly tools and debates concerned with the interpretation of these cultural monuments.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Vampire Stories: Culture, Politics, Science<br /></strong>SLAVIC 162<br />Tomislav Longinovic<br />2016 Spring<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>15738  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160502</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course traces the figure of the vampire from its roots in Slavic folklore to the icon of contemporary popular culture.  Using innovative methodology of cultural translation, it provides students with in-depth analysis of the way vampire “travels” from its legendary Balkan homeland to the Hollywood studios.  Starting with medical and theological treatises on the first appearances of this undead revenant in c18, the course follows its transformation into a figure of Gothic literature during c19 and its domination of the horror genre in film and television during c20.  The focus of the course is on the way collective political anxieties are projected into this figure of popular culture over the ages.</p>
<p><strong>Class Notes:</strong> Taught by Visiting Professor, Tomislav Z. Longinović.</p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>[Sumerian Myths and Epics]<br /></strong>SUMERIAN 141<br />Piotr Steinkeller<br />Likely to be offered in 2017 Spring<br /><strong>Course ID: </strong>113378</p>
<p></p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong>Seminar: Welsh Bardic Poetry<br /></strong>WELSH 227<br />Catherine McKenna<br />2016 Spring<br />Thursday, 02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>11913  <strong>Course ID: </strong>111774</p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Readings from the <em>hengerdd</em>, the <em>beirdd y tywysogion</em> and the <em>beirdd yr uchelwyr</em>; consideration of the social and political contexts of their poetry, its forms, and its relationship to other medieval European poetic traditions.</p>
<p><strong>Recommended Prep:</strong> Knowledge of Welsh or permission of the instructor.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&amp;M at 50                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-1013391" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="744" width="1000" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/fm_symposium_poster_revised2.png?m=1499882345&amp;itok=RpepVtrF" alt="" title="" /></p><p>(Please note: this schedule is largely final, but some adjustments and updates may still be made.)</p><p> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"><strong>Thursday March 2</strong></p><p style="margin-left:.5in">5.00     Welcome &amp; opening remarks (Stephen Mitchell, chair)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">5.15     Keynote: "Fifty Years in Folklore" — Robert Teske '70 </p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.15     Dinner</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.15     Performance — Kate Chadbourne (harp)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.30     David Lerner ’88 — MD, Medical Officer at FDA</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">7.45     Albert Lord / F&amp;M tribute (Gregory Nagy &amp; Joseph Nagy ‘74)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in"><strong>Friday March 3</strong></p><p style="margin-left:.5in">8.45     Coffee</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.00     Welcome — Stephen Mitchell</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.05     The Milman Parry Collection - David Elmer</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">9.30     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; Our Lives</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Deborah Foster</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Katherine Griffis ‘78 — Rev., United Presbyterian Church, Hornell, NY</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Winnie Li ’00 — Author, activist, PhD cand. London School of Economics</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Montana Miller ’96 — Assoc. Prof. of Popular Culture, Bowling Green State University</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Devi Lockwood ’14 — youth delegate with SustainUS to U.N. climate talks in Morocco</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• William Westerman '81 — New Jersey City University</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Louis Monoyudis ’98 — COO, Supply Pod</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">11.30   Performance — Montana Miller ’96 — storytelling, performance</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">12.00   Lunch</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">1:00     Performance — Devi Lockwood ’14 — storytelling</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">1.15     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; the World</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Joseph Nagy '74</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Maja Groff ’01 — Senior Legal Officer at the Permanent Bureau, Hague Conference on Private International Law</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Susan E. Keller ’83 — Assoc. Dean of Academic Affairs, Western State College of Law</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Terrell McSweeny ’97 — Commissioner, Federal Trade Commission</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Ruth Goldstein — Harvard College Fellow and F&amp;M Cttee Member</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Lowell Brower — PhD Cand. in Harvard AAAS and Asst. Head Tutor, F&amp;M</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">3.30     Performance — Becca Nesson ’98 — Berkman Center for Internet &amp; Society, Harvard Law School</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">3.45     Coffee</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">4.00     Roundtable — Folklore &amp; the Future</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">                  • Moderator: Lowell Brower </p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• William Moore ‘85 — Assoc. Professor of American Material Culture, Boston Univ., &amp; Director, American &amp; New England Studies Program</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Merrill Kaplan ‘94 — Assoc. Prof. of Scandinavian Studies and Folklore, Ohio State Univ.</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• Lowell Brower — PhD Cand. in Harvard AAAS and Asst. Head Tutor, F&amp;M</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• current students — all juniors and seniors</p><p style="margin-left:81.0pt">• discussion</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.00     Performances — Brendan Bulger ’96 (video); Maggie Harrison ’07 (singing)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in">6.30     Roundtable: current &amp; former chairs &amp; head tutors (Greg Nagy, Joe Harris, Maria Tatar, Steve Mitchell, Hugh Flick, Deborah Foster)</p><p style="margin-left:.5in"> </p><p style="margin-left:.5in">            Reception to follow</p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50"  class="active-trail active active"><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics/courses" >COURSES</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Freshman Seminars                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138161" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>08/18/2016:</strong> update with 2016-17 courses.</p>
<p><strong><span><a href="https://portal.my.harvard.edu">Harvard Course Search page.</a></span></strong></p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>The Art of Storytelling<br />FRSEMR 32V</strong></span><br />Deborah Foster<br /><strong>2017 Spring<br />Tuesday, </strong>02:00pm - 03:59pm<br /><strong>Location:</strong> <span style="color:#808080">Warren House, Room 102</span><br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>13644  <strong>Course ID: </strong>122447<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor<br /><br /><strong>Description: </strong><span>Throughout the centuries and across all continents, men and women have told stories to express the values they find in their common experiences of everyday life. While the multiple storytelling traditions of the teller influence the content and form of the emergent tale, each narrator shapes the story to reflect his or her own intentions, making it personally expressive as well as publicly meaningful to a particular audience in a specific place and time. Drawing on scholarship of oral storytelling traditions and reading (in translation) myths, tales, legends, plays and other forms from several traditions, this seminar will examine the nature of storytelling, its enduring appeal, and its ability to adapt to multiple new platforms (stage, print, film, internet). Participants will engage in the storytelling process itself in order to understand better the interrelationship of structure, plot, character, imagery, rhythm, voice and gesture to the story as a whole in a variety of media, ranging from mime to video.</span></p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Folklore and the Culture of Childhood<br />FRSEMR 36J</strong></span><br />Maria Tatar<br />2016 Fall<br /><strong>Wednesday,</strong> 03:00pm - 04:59pm<br /><strong>Location:</strong> <span style="color:#ff0000">Warren House 102</span><br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16259  <strong>Course ID: </strong>160202<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>12  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>This course begins by examining the stories of Charles Perrault, the Brothers Grimm, and Hans Christian Andersen and explores the migration of fairy tales into literary and cinematic cultures for adults and for children. From fairy tales we turn to fantasy literature and to the great counterfactuals in Other Worlds constructed for children. Lewis Carroll's <em>Alice in Wonderland</em>, J.M. Barrie's <em>Peter Pan</em>, J.K. Rowling's <em>Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows</em>, and Neil Gaiman's <em>Ocean at the End of the Lane</em> will guide us through our investigation of what Graham Greene called the "excitement and revelation" of books read in childhood. </p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p></p>
<p><span style="color:#800000"><strong>Comparative Historical Mythology<br />FRSEMR 36S</strong></span><br />Michael Witzel<br />2016 Fall<br /><strong>Thursday,</strong> 04:00pm - 05:59pm<br /><strong>Location:</strong> <span style="color:#ff0000">Barker Center 211</span><br /><strong>Class Number: </strong>16522  <strong>Course ID: </strong>109498<br /><strong>Class Capacity: </strong>15  <strong>Consent Required: </strong>Instructor</p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p><strong>Description: </strong>Deals with an innovative approach to comparative mythology by incorporating an <em>historical</em> approach, not by the commonly assumed archetypes or diffusion. Working backwards from our earliest written sources (Egypt, etc.), successively earlier stages are detected through repeated reconstructions. Recent developments in genetics, archaeology, linguistics support the proposed historical model that tentatively reaches back to the "African Eve". Testing the proposal offers a wide scope for students participation and research in texts and in the sciences. Open to Freshmen only.</p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p><strong><span></span></strong></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390598424" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390598424"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390598424' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168496" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/snow-queen.jpg?m=1492187823">snow-queen.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/snow-queen.jpg?m=1499734798&amp;itok=xgKgKuAm" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-46866"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics"  class="active-trail active"><span>Academics</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-46871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/advising-0" ><span>Advising</span></a></li><li class="expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-47651"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics/courses"  class="active-trail active"><span>Courses</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-3 menu-item-48441"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/cross-listed-courses" ><span>Cross-Listed Courses</span></a></li><li class="last leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-3 menu-item-48446"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/freshman-seminars"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Freshman Seminars</span></a></li></ul></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-48431"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" ><span>Concentration Requirements</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48486"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field" ><span>Secondary Field</span></a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48526"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/swapna-dev-memorial-book-prize" ><span>The Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>
		<!--footer region beg-->
		<footer id="footer" class="clearfix" role="contentinfo">

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>

    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      General Exams                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138186" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style">The Concentration also administers a two-part General Exam in the Spring of the Senior Year, just after the end of classes.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><strong><span class="style_2">Part One</span></strong><span class="style"> of the General Exam is a three-hour written essay examination concerned with broad theoretical issues and is taken by all Seniors together.  It is usually scheduled on the first Monday of reading period (usually the first Monday in May).</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><strong><span class="style_2">Part Two</span></strong><span class="style"> is a brief oral presentation on the thesis followed by questions posed by Committee Members.  This is not a thesis defense, although there will be time for the student to talk about their thesis or senior project.  The oral exam lasts from 45 minutes to 1 hour.  Oral exams are held on the Tuesday-Thursday after the written exam.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390597438" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390597438"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597438' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168446" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/new-england-headstone.jpg?m=1492187794">new-england-headstone.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/new-england-headstone.jpg?m=1499865188&amp;itok=wqOVBFJ_" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail 					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/senior-theses-senior-projects" >SENIOR THESES &amp; SENIOR PROJECTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Grants for Research                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138236" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_3">A number of university-based organizations sponsor grants for undergraduates that are designed to support thesis research. Among the most notable are:<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_6" href="http://www.seo.harvard.edu/" title="http://www.seo.harvard.edu/">The Student Employment Office</a><span class="style_3"> (click on Research Programs)</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_6" href="http://www.hds.harvard.edu/cswr/" title="http://www.hds.harvard.edu/cswr/">Center for World Religions</a><span class="style_3"> <br /><br /></span><a class="style_6" href="http://www.wcfia.harvard.edu/" title="http://www.wcfia.harvard.edu/">The Center for International Affairs</a><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_3">The Alpha Iota Chapter of </span><a class="style_6" href="http://www.pbk.org/" title="http://www.pbk.org/">Phi Beta Kappa</a><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_3">Private organizations also support grants that can be used for thesis research, such as </span><a class="style_6" href="http://www.fordfound.org/" title="http://www.fordfound.org/">The Ford Program for Undergraduate Research</a><span class="style_3">. For details concerning these and other grants you may be qualified for, consult the current </span><a class="style_6" href="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/publications/gtg.htm" title="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/publications/gtg.htm">Harvard College Guide to Grants</a><span class="style_3">, available at the </span><a class="style_6" href="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/index.htm" title="http://www.ocs.fas.harvard.edu/index.htm">Office of Career Services</a><span class="style_3">, 54 Dunster St.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390597583" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390597583"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597583' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168471" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/hex-barn1.jpg?m=1492187810">hex-barn1.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/hex-barn1.jpg?m=1500180788&amp;itok=RPMJ5AeV" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail <div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-137976 header-left header-main content-top footer-left footer-right content-top-slideshow-enabled">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>
		  </header>
      <!--header regions end-->
		
				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-900 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" 					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" >2003: &quot;ALL EYEZ ON ME: TUPAC SHAKUR AND THE SEARCH FOR THE MODERN FOLK HERO&quot;</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      "Harvard Gazette: Symposium analyzes, celebrates 'thug'"                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-931226" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><img height="857" width="549" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.15.51_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=gncfh-qj" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="805" width="551" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.07_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=TF_NWe7G" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="701" width="541" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.19_am.png?m=1477329406&amp;itok=EOsTKu1E" alt="" title="" /></p><p><img height="823" width="551" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/screen_shot_2016-10-24_at_11.16.29_am.png?m=1500696469&amp;itok=jY16i3ZI" alt="" title="" /></p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century"
