			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Junior &amp; Senior Tutorials                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138176" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><ul><li>The Junior Tutorial (FM 98b)</li>
<li>The Senior Tutorial for the Non-Thesis Capstone Option (FM 96r)</li>
<li>The Senior Tutorial for the Senior Thesis (FM 99)</li>
</ul><p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>The Junior Tutorial</strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2">The Junior Tutorial, <strong>Folklore and Mythology 98b</strong>, is a one-on-one tutorial with a scholar specializing in the student’s Special Field; ordinarily, it is taken in the spring semester of the junior year. The purpose of the tutorial is to provide an overview of the Special Field at its intersection with Folklore, focusing on two or three areas, one of which may be develped into the Senior Thesis.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2">The Junior Tutorial is designed and implemented by each student and his or her tutor. Students should meet with their tutors at the very beginning of the term to discuss the format, meeting schedule, syllabus and reading for the Tutorial. Students will be expected to write a substantial amount during the tutorial. Writing options may include several small papers, two or three medium length papers, or one long paper. A copy of the syllabus and one of the written works should be given to the Head Tutor’s office.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2">Students should speak with the Head Tutor and/or his or her Special Field adviser before the term begins to identify an appropriate tutor.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><strong><span style="font-size:large">The Senior Tutorial for the Non-Thesis Capstone Option</span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">During the senior year, we expect students concentrating in Folklore &amp; Mythology to demonstrate their command of cultural theory an analysis.  In the capstone option, <strong>Folklore and Mythology 96r</strong>, such competence may be demonstrated through, for example, a performance, exhibit, or written analysis, usually in connection with specific Folklore and Mythology courses (or related courses approved by the Head Tutor). </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">Please check back here soon for more detail about this option, which will become official for the 2011-2012 academic year.  Or, please arrange a meeting with Deborah Foster to discuss this developing option.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>The Senior Tutorial for the Senior Thesis</strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4">The Senior Thesis, <strong>Folklore and Mythology 99</strong>, is required of all concentrators and is regarded as a year-long opportunity to bring the theoretical concerns common to all folklorists together with the student’s own Special Field.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"> In this section you will find specific information about the thesis for those writing in the Folklore and Mythology program (e.g., requirements, deadlines, etc.) and general advice about the thesis project for all Folklore and Mythology concentrators.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">Students seeking general advice about writing a thesis should be forewarned that the following recommendations are just that: recommendations. Every person has his or her own strategies for working and writing. The advice offered here is meant to serve as a guideline according to which you will be able to determine your own best approach to this substantial undertaking.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">(For a reminder of Deadlines, see the main <a href="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/folklore/senior-theses-senior-projects">Senior Thesis</a> page.)</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">Writing a senior thesis should be the culmination of a student’s undergraduate career. Work on a thesis offers an opportunity to explore an issue that engages you, to plan and direct your own work, and to draw on the knowledge of methodology and material that you have gained from course work in the concentration. Many seniors have praised the thesis project as the best learning experience of their lives. It is the intellectual adventure of shaping an idea and finding its articulate expression.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5">The first stages of the thesis project—choosing a topic and an adviser—are perhaps the most difficult. The cardinal rule is to begin early. You should start to think seriously about a topic area and possible advisers during the spring semester of your Junior year. We expect you to contact a potential adviser in the spring and discuss your ideas then. The faculty member can give you valuable advice at that early stage and suggest reading and research for the summer. In addition, there are a number of strategies that you can employ to help you define a topic and find an adviser.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Out-of-Phase Concentrators                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138191" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_1">Folklore and Mythology students who have taken a one-semester leave or are for any other reason proceeding through the program a semester out of phase should discuss their plans thoroughly with the Head Tutor.</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_3">Note: There are special calendar deadlines regarding Senior Tutorial and General Exams for out-of-phase students.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597583' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168471" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/hex-barn1.jpg?m=1492187810">hex-barn1.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/hex-barn1.jpg?m=1500180788&amp;itok=RPMJ5AeV" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences" >SYMPOSIUMS &amp; CONFERENCES</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" >2016: CELEBRATING ANOTHER HARMONY: SOUTH ASIAN FOLKLORE IN THE 21ST CENTURY</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Participant Titles &amp; Abstracts                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-662881" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><strong>**********************</strong></p>
<p><strong>KEYNOTE ADDRESS<br />Friday, April 8, 2016 - 6:00 pm, Barker Center 133</strong></p>
<p>**********************</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Margaret Mills, Ohio State University (Professor Emerita) </p>
<p><em>How Stories Lodge in Lives</em><em> </em></p>
<p>Mary Frere’s <em>Old Deccan Days</em> (1868) introduction to the storyteller, Anna Liberata deSouza, abundantly illustrates how the performer’s choices among traditional stories reflected specific challenges of a personal life full of loss. Frere’s framing of the stories set a model for attention to individual artistry and contexts of performance not again pursued in South Asia till the mid-20<sup>th</sup> century, with the performance turn in folklore studies. In recent decades, Wadley, Gold and Raheja, Narayan, Prasad, Naithani, and Narasamamba, among others, developed text presentations and analyses linking repertoire, performance, and personal history in various ways.  As Ramanujan has pointed out, <em>vrat katha</em> itself is a major ritual genre in which the telling of stories shapes performatively the lives of the tellers and listeners, both in the ostensibly biographical miracle narratives framed within the ritual and the lives of the ritual participants who keep the stories alive. Blackburn’s  <em>Another Harmony</em> itself offered a foundational analysis of relationships of biography, narrative performance genre and ritual efficacy in South Asia.  The present paper reviews trajectories of this complex from biography to ritual studies and ends with some reflections on why the studies of performed narrative in and of lives have more usually, though not exclusively, focused on women protagonists and performers. Are we missing parallels in men’s equally situated narrative performances, or is there a systematic difference in performative focus determined by genre and/or gender?</p>
<p> </p>
<p> _________________________________________________________________________</p>
<p><strong>SYMPOSIUM PANELS</strong><br /><strong>Saturday, April 9, 2016 - 9:00 am - 6:00 pm - Thompson Room, Barker Center</strong></p>
<p></p>
<p align="center"><strong>UNDERGRADUATE STUDENT PANEL</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Aniket De, Tufts University </p>
<p><em>Divided Songs, Altered Gods: Partition, Nationalism, and Performance in the Bengal Borderland</em></p>
<p>This paper studies the history of the Gambhira, a popular performance on either side of the India-Bangladesh border, mainly in Malda (West Bengal) and Rajshahi (Bangladesh). Gambhira originated from rites of the god Hindu Shiva, and later became a popular theatre form in which both Hindu and Muslim performers complained to Shiva, with ridicule, and sarcasm, about people in power. After the Partition of British India in 1947, many Muslim performers fled across the border to East Pakistan (later Bangladesh). The Muslim performers, in Bangladesh’s Islamic context, replaced the figure of Shiva with that of a Muslim farmer, and continued the performance’s older tradition of questioning authority. The paper explores the interaction between broader structural changes in state structure and the consequent impact on folk forms. I explore the realities of such performances in the borderland, as well as the competing historical metanarratives on the changes and continuities in Gambhira.</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Benjamin D. Grimm, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Trans-gression: Gender, Divinity, and Cross-dressing in</em><em> the Krishna Līl<em>ā</em>hava</em></p>
<p>The <em>līlahāva </em>– a story in which Krishna and Rādhā exchange clothes during a night of passion – is inflected in poetry, art, and drama, and in its many loci cloaks itself in various symbolic modes: as comedic farce, as amorous play, and as a profound act of devotion. The story is imbued by tense dichotomies of male and female, divine and human, unity and disunity: is it transgressive for a cowherdess to wear Krishna’s peacock-feather crown? If so, from what does this transgression spring? The act of crossdressing exhumes basic tensions between male and female in Hindu thought. Moreover, it leads us to question the very nature of Krishna’s divinity; assuming one another’s identity reveals Rādhā as a mirror of Krishna, suggesting that she is indeed a divine consort, an endemic aspect of his own being. Declaring transgression in the <em>līlahāva </em>emerges from cultural – and thus human – prescriptions for a pair who is incontrovertibly transcendent.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p>Megan Taing, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Brotherhood and Humor: Negotiating the South Asian American College Experience</em>  </p>
<p>This study analyzes the interaction among members of an all-male South Asian American club at an American university, contending that humor is the principle method through which members negotiate bicultural tensions. While seemingly raucous, judgmental, or even discriminatory on the surface, their jokes reveal a deeper sentiment of tolerance and support between members of the club. This mentorship vis-à-vis comedy can be invaluable to some South Asian American males transitioning from a stricter home life to more independence in college – including newfound freedom within the academic and romantic relationship domains. By maintaining membership in a South Asian American brotherhood of sorts, these students are able to retain ties to a familiar part of their identities, the “traditional” upbringing and expectations of their parents, while simultaneously exploring and receiving peer feedback on new interests that could contradict the familiar itself.  </p>
<p></p>
<p align="center"><strong>SOUTH ASIAN FOLKLORE IN HISTORICAL PERSPECTIVE</strong></p>
<p> Frank J. Korom, Boston University </p>
<p><em>Three Decades of Folklore Studies in South Asia</em>: <em>Toward a History</em> </p>
<p><em>Another Harmony</em> marked the end of a previous era and signaled a new one in terms of studying South Asian folklore. This paper surveys the past thirty years of folkloristic scholarship on South Asia to identify significant contributions but also to point out gaps in areas of research that demand more and fuller attention. I conclude that while much has been done in the area of verbal art, very little has been done to address material culture. Moreover, the output of work on folklore in South Asia has been predominantly Indocentric, that is to say focusing almost exclusively on India at the expense of that nation’s neighbors in the region. Lastly, an overwhelming majority of the academic literature that one might call “folkloristic” focuses on Hindu traditions, while far less attention has been paid to Islam, and even less on Christianity, Sikhism, Jainism, and Buddhism.</p>
<p><strong> </strong></p>
<p></p>
<p>Adheesh Sathaye, University of British Colombia</p>
<p><em>The Scribal Life of Folktales in Premodern India</em> </p>
<p>This paper will explore how and why, about a thousand years ago, it became popular in India to compile large anthologies of folktales that were told in Sanskrit and disseminated through handwritten manuscripts. Oral variants of these tales are found scattered around the world, and folklorists have long recognized that this diffusion had taken place through an intricate interplay between written and oral modes of transmission. Less understood are the historical motivations for such oral/written interplay, especially within the specific context of the medieval Sanskrit literary culture in which these anthologies were being produced. I propose to sharpen our understanding of the cultural value of folktales in the premodern past, based on the textual history of the <em>Vetāla-pañcaviṃśati</em> (25 Tales of the Animated Corpse) a popular medieval anthology of riddle-tales. I focus on the active role of scribes—both professional and amateur—in carving out a scribal public culture in premodern India, using a combination of folktales, proverbs, and riddles that both complemented and challenged the elite Brahminical intellectual traditions of the time.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p>Leela Prasad, Duke University </p>
<p><em>Nameless in a Great Garden: When English Imperial Conquest Becomes a Purāṇa</em> </p>
<p>My paper will examine a moment on the Indian side of the colonial archive of the anthropology of India to consider an intriguing dramatic poem written by eminent folklorist and literary scholar, P. V. Ramaswami Raju (1852-1897). <em>Sreemat</em> <em>Rajangala Mahodyanam</em>, <em>or The Great Park of The English Raj,</em> is a long poem in Sanskrit with an English translation provided by Raju himself. I will argue that the Raju’s <em>purāṇa</em>-style poem, set in a wondrous garden, operates in two core registers. One register maintains a tension between superlative praise of the English empire and the other is coded criticism about empire itself. I hope to demonstrate that by skillfully incorporating the origin of the English empire (yoked to a narrative about the discovery of America) into a Hindu mythos, Ramaswami Raju is able to project the error of empire as a cosmic error. In this frame, the abrupt ending of the poem, anguished over the namelessness of its protagonist, creates a kind of a moral caesura in the narrative of glory. </p>
<p> <strong> </strong></p>
<p align="center"><strong>SOUTH ASIAN MATERIAL CULTURE &amp; BELIEF</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Joyce Burkhalter Flueckiger, Emory University </p>
<p><em>Standing in Cement: Ravana on the Chhattisgarhi Plains</em> </p>
<p>Over the last two decades, an interdisciplinary focus on the body and visual and material culture has emerged in folklore and religious studies, to counter, in part, the traditional textual/verbal focus of the respective disciplines. This paper is part of a larger study of the agency of materiality in Indian traditions, which analyzes different forms of materiality in ritual and everyday contexts. Here, I focus on the 8-10 foot tall cement images of the <em>rakshasa</em> antagonist Ravana of the Ramayana that are unique to the central Indian state of Chhattisgarh. They stand at village and town centers or on open fields at their outskirts.  Dramatic performances and textual readings are held in front of these images during the festival of Dashera, at the end of which firecrackers are set off around the image to indicate Ravana’s destruction. <em>Narratively</em>, the hero-god Ram kills him; however, <em>materially</em> Ravana lives, standing in cement all year. The permanence of the Ravana physical images creates an alternative theology and worldview to that of verbal epic performances. I argue that the cement Ravanas are <em>material</em> actors.</p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Kirin Narayan, Australian National University </p>
<p><em>Making and Narrating: Vishwakarma Family Stories among Artisans</em><em> </em></p>
<p>Many artisan communities across India trace descent from the Hindu god Vishwakarma, the “Universe Maker.” Identifying themselves by labels marking this family connection—including “Vishwakarmas” or “The Sons of Vishwakarma”—their traditional work was thought to continue their divine ancestor’s making and shaping of the material world. This paper examines themes of making as a form of thinking (Ingold 2013) that pervade the mythology of hereditary artisan castes associated with Vishwakarma (cf. Brouwer 1986). I focus particularly on Gujarat-based family stories and rituals of the goddess Randal Ma, honored as Vishwakarma’s daughter. How, I ask, does this unusually doubled goddess point to larger associations between Vishwakarma kinship, goddess worship, and gendered aspects of making, even as traditional caste occupations have given way to other professions, and the “Make in India” scheme has become a politicized project?</p>
<p> </p>
<p>Puja Sahney, SUNY- Albany </p>
<p><em>Transnational Spaces of Belonging: Immigration Process, Social Ties, and Hindu Homes of Purity  </em><em> </em></p>
<p>This paper discusses the role trans-boundary social and symbolic ties play in shaping the way newly arrived Hindu immigrants from India manage and organize spaces in their suburban American homes around the Hindu notion of “purity.” The focus is on the Hindu domestic shrine, an important religious artifact found in Hindu houses, which influences the movement and behavior of family members and Hindus’ efforts to produce and consume religious spaces within and immediately outside the house. The paper argues that Hindu immigrant homes are transnational spaces of belonging. This transnationality of space is regulated both formally through the lengthy immigration process as well as informally through social ties maintained between people across nations. Using ethnographic data, this paper examines the space-artifact continuum around the notion of purity and how the relationships Hindus build and rebuild with domestic spaces reveal important aspects of their sense of belonging in a new country. </p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Ülo Valk, University of Tartu </p>
<p><em>Where the Goddess Spent her Wedding Night: Place-Lore of the Kāmākhyā Temple in Silghat, Assam</em><em> </em></p>
<p>The paper discusses mythic histories of the temple of Kāmākhyā in Silghat on the southern bank of Brahmaputra in Nagaon district, Assam. It is based on fieldwork, conducted in the temple and the adjacent village intermittently from 2009–2015, concentrating on the stories of three Brahmin families, who have been serving the temple since its establishment in 1745. Especially important is the position of the temple in the mythic landscape of Assam and the strategies of storytelling to enhance its power of narrative gravitation to attract pilgrims. Place-lore about the temple displays some significant discrepancies and disagreements between the narrators who refer to the authority of literary sources but rely on oral traditions of the neighbourhood and on their family histories.</p>
<p>  </p>
<p align="center"><strong>THE POLITICS OF FOLKLORE</strong></p>
<p> </p>
<p>Leah Lowthorp, Harvard University </p>
<p><em>Folklore, Politics, and the State: Kutiyattam and National/Global Heritage in India</em> </p>
<p>In recent decades<em>, </em>scholars of South Asian folklore have increasingly engaged the politics of folklore, interrogating its role in both colonialist, nationalist, and other political agendas. This paper considers the role of expressive culture in Indian postcolonial nation building through the lens of Kutiyattam Sanskrit theater of Kerala state, recognized as India’s first UNESCO Masterpiece of the Oral and Intangible Heritage of Humanity in 2001. Through an examination of the art’s relationship with India’s national academy for dance, drama, and music, the Sangeet Natak Akademi, it traces state heritage discourse and practice over a fifty year period. It thereby explores the (re)production of the State’s role as arts patron and cultural educator, as well as a sustained state-level promotion of artistic continuity through creative adaptation and change.</p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p>Shakthi Nataraj, University of California, Berkeley </p>
<p><em>Critical Folkloristics and the Study of Transgender Women’s Communities in South India</em> </p>
<p>Scholars in the emerging field of "critical folkloristics" have criticized notions of folklore that distinguish it from "modern" institutions, emphasizing instead how notions of modernity and traditionality actively shape one another. My research examines the <em>jamath</em> (family) system of Tamil Nadu's <em>thirunangai </em>(transgender woman) communities that has lately become the object of much controversy amongst LGBT activists. Some see these precolonial kinship structures, placing <em>guru</em>s (mentors), above <em>chela</em>s (disciples), as outdated feudal relics, at odds with "modern" notions of equality. Representatives of transnational non-profits similarly argue that <em>jamath</em>s<em> </em>compromise <em>thirunangai'</em>s abilities to effectively make "objective" decisions. Examining narratives of kinship by transgender women that manage and staff a Community Based Organization in Chennai, I argue that the logic of <em>jamath</em> kinship, far from being an outdated relic, both shapes and is shaped by the politics of international LGBT and HIV activism, and the functioning of Community Based Organizations. </p>
<p> </p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p></p>
<p>Finnian Gerety, Brown University </p>
<p><em>The Amplified Sacrifice: Sound, Technology, and Participation in Vedic Rituals in Kerala </em> </p>
<p>For generations, Nambudiri Brahmins of Kerala have performed sacrifices based on liturgies of the first millennium BCE. While their praxis evokes the ideal of an archaic, unchanging sacrifice, the soundscape of Nambudiri ritual culture in recent years has come to reflect technological shifts in Indian society: microphones and megawatt speakers now amplify mantras well beyond the power of the human voice. This paper examines the amplified sacrifice, arguing that local amplification of performances tracks with a regional "amplification" of the cultural prominence of Vedic ritual. This feedback loop increases the participation of non-Nambudiris in the funding, organization, and celebration of such rituals, which are now carried out as festivals with thousands of attendees and a full suite of marketing, media coverage, and VIPs.</p>
<p> </p>
<p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

				</div>

					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/senior-theses-senior-projects" >SENIOR THESES &amp; SENIOR PROJECTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>

															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Past Thesis Topics                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138216" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_4">Selected Past Thesis Topics</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="style_3">LATEST:</span></strong></span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Consuming Transformation: Eating, Drinking, and the Otherworld in Celtic and Scandinavian Folklore and Mythology (2004)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Entre Rêve et Réalité: Narrative, Craft, and Identity In the Vineyards of the Touraine (2004)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Emperor and Xuanwu: Interactions between a Myth and the Establishment as Found in the </span><span class="style_5">Beiyou Ji</span><span class="style"> and other Pre-Qing Sources (2004)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Santa Made Me Do It: the Creation of Social and Family Unity Through Christmas Rituals and Values (2004)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_5">Sin Acento</span><span class="style">: Dynamics of Cultural Identity in a Modern Tejano Family (2004)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Compassionate Promiscuity: Women, Sex, and Enlightenment in Chinese Buddhist Literature (2003)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">For Such a Tomb: the Craftsman in Indo-European Myth and Society (2003)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Game-Ending Heroics: The role of the athlete in Homeric Greece and Modern Rome (2003)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">"He Said to You, There Was an Old Man...": Storytelling in the High Atlas Mountains (2003)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">(Re)presenting a Nation: Sport, Art, Culture, and Chinese Figure Skating (2003)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Creating Imitation: An Investigation of the Wiccan Approach to Ritual as a Means of Negotiating Individual and Group Spirituality (2002)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Feeling 'Tribal': Western Interpretation of Non-Western Body Art (2002)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Folklore and its Relationship to Modern Media: an Examination of Buffy the Vampire Slayer (2002)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Popular Theater of Dario Fo, Modern Day </span><span class="style_5">Giullare</span><span class="style"> (2002)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Sword Makes the Man: Weapons and the Construction of Social Identity in Viking Age Scandinavia (2002)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Love, Politics, and National Identity: Images of Prince Charles Edward Stuart in a Gaelic and Scots Jacobite Song from the Eighteenth Century (2000)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Quest of Kinship: The Family in Filipino Folklore and Immigration (2000)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Blues Queen Mystique: Putting the Classic Blues Onstage (1999)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Folklore in the Poetry of Nuala Ní Dhomhnaill (1999)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">"That’s a basic Chinese immigrant story, you know": Narratives of Immigration and the Construction of Ethnic Identity in the Chinese-Bahamian Community (1999)</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4"> <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><span style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="style_3">PAST:</span></strong></span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">‘The Interplay of Trance’ Storytelling and Social Change in the Life Histories of Two Fijian Healers</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">A Discussion of the Fasting and Food Piety of Three Late Medieval Women Mystics: Saint Catherine of Siena, Margery Kempe, and St. Catherine of Genoa</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">A Structural Analysis of Conflict Mediation in Three Types of Tlingit Ceremonial Interactions.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">A Structural and Historical Analysis of the Legend of the Jewish Pope</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">A Study of King Horn and Havelock the Dane.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">A Study of Modern Witchcraft and the Influence of the Kabbalah Upon It.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Adder’s Tongue, Daffy’s Elixir and Ophioglossum Vulgatum: The Fragmentation of Herbal Folk Medicine in America 1750-1850</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">An Analysis of Anglo-Saxon Charms</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">An Analysis of Structural Aspects in the Romanian Oral Epic Song.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Angels in Caesarius of Heisterbach’s Dialogus Miraculorum: Learned and Oral Inteplay in the Exempla Collection of a Thirteenth-Century Cistercian Monk.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Apinaye Mythology and the Origin of the White Man</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Água de Beber: An Interdisciplinary Study of Capoeira–The Art of the Free</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Bees in Celtic Tradition</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Children’s Folklore in Performative Context</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Christ and His Brothers as Reflections of the Developing Child in Zinacantan</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Comic Characters in the Icelandic Family Sagas</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Dancing the Real Reel: A Diachronic Study of Entextualization and the Embodied Dancer in the Royal Scottish Country Dance Society, Boston Branch</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Diana in the Canon Episcopi: Imagination or Folk Belief?</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Discovering the Wonder in Wonder Tales</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Divine Grace in Archaic Greek Tradition</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Dying for a Wake, an Analysis of Traditional Waking Practices Through the Folklore Concepts of Ritual, Rite of Passage, and Festival</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Dynamics and Syncretism Among the Nevada Paiutes</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Elvis as Hero of Global Village Culture</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Entierros de Cuba: An Examination of Eight Cuban Legends of Buried Treasure</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Folktale and Social Structure: An Analysis of Traditional Chinese Folktales.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Form and Function in the Religious Structure of Medieval Scandinavia.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Formula for Ecstasy: Ritual Efficacy in the Practice of Witchcraft.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">From Dance Hall to Pub: Irish Traditional Music Events in Boston 1950-1997</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Gymanist Approaching Folkloric Event</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Hard to Swallow: The Form and Meaning of Women’s Oral Sex Talk</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Hearing Appalachian Voices: Southern West Virginia Women’s Perceptions of the Dominant Woman</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Hervarar saga ok Heithreks: Boundaries of Heroism and Wisdom.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">“Hey, I Didn’t Write This, Folks. . . But I’m Singing It”: An Examination of the Repertoire and Composition Processes of a Northern Anglo-American Blues Singer.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Immrama as a Chronicle of Irish History and the Evolution of Irish Religious Belief and Practice.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">In the Face of a Thousand Sorrows: Seacht Suáilce Na Maighdine The Seven Joys of the Virgin</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Irish Fairy Gifts: AT503, The Gifts of the Little People, in Ireland</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">“Jävla utlanningar!”: Ethnocentric Legend Tradition in Sweden</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">La Virgen de Guadalupe and the Symbolic Roots of Cultural Change</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Lady’s Day: Ritual as Community Self-Definition in a Greek Tourist Town</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Living Under the Cattle: The Pastoral Ethic and Massai Sacrifice.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Maize as Mediator: A Structural Analysis of the Popol Vuh</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Melodic Stability and Variability in Northern Chinese Drum Singing.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Merit, Status and Society: An Introductory Essay on Culture and Change in Cambodia.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Music in the Jamaican Pentecostal Churches.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Myth, Dream and Amythic Consciousness in Tibetan Buddhism.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Navigating Dangerous Seas: The Female Pirate Gráinne Ní Mháille and Irish Narratives</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Odin and Ecstacy: The Shamanistic Qualities of Scaldic Poetry</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">On the Study of Slavic Paganism</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Oskudólgur and Faroese Society</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Pele and Hiiaka: Structuralism and Hawaiian Myth</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Psychodynamic Tensions in Maya Culture</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Re-evaluating Ragnarök: An Examination of the Gosforth Cross as a Celtic Christian Monument</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Remarks on the Means and Patterns of Folktale Transmission in Ireland</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Ritual and the Emergence of Mexican-American Identity in Fiesta San Antonio</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Sentiments and Symbols in the Grimm’s Kinder-und-Hausmärchen.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Sexual Humorous Tales in Norwegian Folklore</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Shield of Heracles: Identity Through Crisis.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">“Ska vi ta kaffe nu?”: Objects of Cultural Recognition and the Death of a Swedish-American Community</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Social Life in South Africa: The Songs of Miriam Makeba</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Songs and Creative Play in French and American Children’s Circle Games: A Comparative Study</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">“Starvin’ Like Marvin”: Factors in Text and Context that Affect Emergent Children’s Folklore</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Structural Types in Zuni Mythology</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Take These Chains: Jimmie Rodgers, Hank William, and the Emergence of the Personal Voice in American Country Music.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Telling Time: Temporal Aspects of Orality, Literacy, and Folklore Genre<br />The 1890 Ghost Dance: A Study of Reality Reconstruction Among the Nevada Paiutes.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Bell Witch of Mississippi and Tennessee: a Historical Analysis of a Southern Legend</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Character of Balaam as Villain in Midrash Numbers Rabbah.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Concept of Public and Private Music in Three North American Indian Tribes</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Development of an Indian Identity: A Study of the Gay Head Indians</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Diction of Violence in Beowulf and the Mwindo Epic.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Discourse Between Interpretive Systems: Modern Medicine and Traditional Healing in Africa</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Effects of Fairy Tale Violence on Kindergarten-Age Children: A Cross-Cultural Analysis</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Evolution of the Hwarang Image: A Theory of National Symbology</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Finest Kind? A Study of Marginalization, in Folklore and Narrative, among Fishermen and Scallopers in New Bedford, Massachusetts</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Gun, the Hero, and the Myth of Survival in Urban America</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Heroic Function of Arjuna in the Mahabharata.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Holistic Power of Hallucinogens: Neuropharmacology and Shamanic Use in Healing and Religion.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Ideal Rapport for Field Work in Japan<br />The Impact of Modernization on Folk Culture: A Case Study Using American Mining Folklore.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Liminal Quality of the Hunt as Portrayed in the Finn Cycle</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Manufactured Minority: Purity, Practicality, or Positional Superioty–the Symbolic, Economic, and Structural Roles of Japan’s Burakumin</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Metaphor of the Road in Pindaric Poetry.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Metaphorical Functions of the Cuentos de Juan Bob</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Negotiation of Ethnic Identity: Multifaceted Images of Lama Meat in La Paz, Bolivia</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Origins of Death among the Bantu Baganda</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Poetic and the Musical Device of Tsakisma in the Folk Song of Crete, Kasos and Karpathos.</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Representation of Women in Traditional Tibetan Narrative</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Ritual of the Passion in the Spanish-American Community of Truchas, New Mexico</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Sicilian Puppet Theater: A Dying Art Form</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Structure of the Voodoo Belief System</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Study of American Coal Mining Music</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Tales of Rabbi Nahman of Bratslav: Audience and Objectives</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Totem Pole in Kwakiutl Society</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">They Have Washed Their Robes: Ghost Shirts of the American Plains</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">‘Thus there are devils, there are spirits’: Genre, Personal Experience, and Belief in Folkloristics and the Words of a Welsh Storyteller</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Trenchtown Rock: a Study of Jamaica’s Reggae Music</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Ture, Ajapa and Wakalulu: Three Diverse African Tricksters</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Widows for the Burning: Rethinking the Historiography of Sati</span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Women in Navaho Culture and Society: Rethinking B. Ortner’s “Is Female to Male as Nature is to Culture?”</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390597690" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390597690"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597690' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168486" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/southwest-pottery.jpg?m=1492187814">southwest-pottery.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/southwest-pottery.jpg?m=1499746070&amp;itok=W9q9NZAN" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>

		  <div class="branding-left"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/profiles/openscholar/themes/hwpi_basetheme/images/harvard-logo.png" width="235" height="32" alt="Harvard Logo" /></a></div><div class="branding-right"><a href="http://www.harvard.edu" >HARVARD.EDU</a></div>		</div>

<div id="page" class="container page os_pages-section-131481 header-left header-main content-top footer-left footer-right content-top-slideshow-enabled">
	<div id="page-wrapper">

		
					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>
			  </div>
		  </header>
      <!--header regions end-->
		
				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/senior-theses-senior-projects" >SENIOR THESES &amp; SENIOR PROJECTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Researching &amp; Writing                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138231" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_2"><span style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="style">THE INITIAL STAGES</span></strong></span><span class="style_1"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">The first stages of research should begin during the summer after your Junior year. This is a time to undertake both background and theoretical reading. Your work will lead you to take the first steps in moving from topic to argument, perhaps the most important aspect of the whole thesis project. A topic is a well-defined area of interest; an argument consists of the point you want to make about your topic and the reasons that support it.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">When you return in the Fall, it will be time to set about more focused research. Refining your topic and determining your argument is part persistence and part trial and error. You should expect to write a number of drafts of every part of the thesis project. Thoughts that are not written down may be lost and, furthermore, are impossible for your adviser to address in detail. Joint concentrators must follow the joint department’s tutorial guidelines and calendar.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_1"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_2"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>EXTENDED RESEARCH AND WRITING</strong></span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_3">Once you have completed your prospectus, you will begin an extended period of research and writing. A project as large as a thesis should be done incrementally. Plan to work on your chapters separately—first researching, then writing. At this stage observing a strict timetable is essential. Set aside time for intense research on a given chapter. When that time is up, start writing immediately. Of course, research will not stop completely until you begin editing your thesis, but succumbing to the temptation to continue research will prevent you from pacing your writing properly. The more you work over each chapter, the better your thesis will be. And remember, as long as you start writing early, you will have time to reopen any line of research later on.</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><strong><span class="style_3">A requirement of approximately 15-20 pages (the “first chapter”) to be submitted to the office of the Head Tutor by the Tuesday after Thanksgiving has been established by the program in order to encourage you to begin writing early.</span></strong><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_3">In the process of writing, you are bound to meet with a variety of difficulties. Your thesis adviser can be instrumental in working through certain problems, but do not hesitate to make use of informal advisers. Talk over your difficulties with your friends and also tutors and Teaching Fellows. Perhaps even show a draft to someone who knows nothing about your topic, as a test of how well your ideas are coming across. The Writing Center, located in the basement of Barker Center, can be a valuable source of advice on the mechanics of writing. The Center offers special help on senior theses in addition to its regular services: conferences by appointment and drop-in hours, not to mention a wide array of handouts and reference books on writing.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390597438" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390597438"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597438' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168446" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/new-england-headstone.jpg?m=1492187794">new-england-headstone.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/new-england-headstone.jpg?m=1499865188&amp;itok=wqOVBFJ_" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail 					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Resources                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-131501" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><strong><span><span>On this page:</span> </span></strong></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<ul><li>Harvard Links</li>
<li>Folklore &amp; Mythology Links</li>
<li>Library Resources</li>
<li>Journals</li>
</ul><p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span><strong><span>HARVARD  LINKS</span></strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a href="https://lrc.fas.harvard.edu">Language Resource Center</a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a href="http://undergrad-research.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do" title="http://undergrad-research.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do">Undergraduate Research at Harvard</a> (opportunities, responsibilities, and helpful resources on campus)</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a href="http://www.gse.harvard.edu/academics/masters/tep/description/utep.html">Undergraduate Teacher Education Program (UTEP)<br /></a>UTEP is a pre-professional teaching program available to all Harvard undergradute students. This elective program combines coursework at the Graduate School of Education and field work in Boston, Cambridge, and Somerville public schools. Students who complete all of UTEP's requirements receive an educator license at the middle or high school level in the Commonwealth of Massachusetts and the states with which Massachusetts has licensure reciprocity. </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a href="http://www.gse.harvard.edu/academics/masters/tep/description/utep.html"> </a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span><strong><span>FOLKLORE &amp; MYTHOLOGY LINKS</span></strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><a class="style_1" href="http://www.afsnet.org/" title="http://www.afsnet.org/">American Folklore Society</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><a class="style_3" href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/folklife/" title="http://lcweb.loc.gov/folklife/">American Folklife Center</a><span>, the Library of Congress</span><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><a class="style_3" href="http://lcweb.loc.gov/folklife/source/grad.html" title="http://lcweb.loc.gov/folklife/source/grad.html">Higher Education Programs in Folklore &amp; Folklife</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><a class="style_3" href="http://urbanlegends.about.com/" title="http://urbanlegends.about.com/">Urban Legends and Folklore<br /></a>Featuring both an archive, and current news debunking 'net rumors and categorizing emergent urban legends.</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><a class="style_1" href="http://www.chs.harvard.edu/mpc/" title="http://www.chs.harvard.edu/mpc/">The Milman Parry Collection of Oral Literature</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span><strong>LIBRARY RESOURCES</strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a href="http://isites.harvard.edu/icb/icb.do?keyword=k25081&amp;pageid=icb.page117906" title="http://isites.harvard.edu:80/icb/icb.do?keyword=k25081&amp;pageid=icb.page117906">Traditions: Research Guide for Folklore &amp; Folkloristics (Harvard College Library)</a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><strong><span>Quick Guide to Harvard Library Electronic Resources For Folklore and Mythology</span></strong><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span><strong>Indexes to Scholarly Journals</strong><br /></span><span>The resources below all index topics in ethnography, ethnology, ethnomusicology, folklore, folk narrative and oral narrative, and myth. They provide links to full-text on-line for many – but not all – of the articles they reference.</span><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:mlabibli" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:mlabibli">MLA International Bibliography</a><span><br /></span><span>Indexes material from 1926 to the present, covering periodical articles (including review essays but not individual book reviews), articles in edited volumes, books, and dissertations</span><span>.</span><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthplus" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthplus">Anthropology Plus (RLG)</a><span><br /></span><span>Combined index that allows joint searching of the two indexes below (which are also available separately):<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthrlit" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthrlit">Anthropological Literature</a><span>, produced by Harvard’s Tozzer Library, covering periodical articles and articles from edited books from the mid-19th century to the present<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthrind" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:anthrind">Anthropological Index</a><span>, produced by the Royal Anthropological Institute, covering periodical article from 1957 to the present.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:arthumci" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:arthumci">Arts and Humanities Citation Index (ISI Web of Science)</a><span> <br /></span><span>Indexes periodical articles in the arts and humanities from 1975 to the present. Using this index, it is possible to search the bibliographies (“cited reference lists”) of articles and to explore connections among various articles and authors. <br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span><strong>Searchable Electronic Journal Collections</strong></span><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:jstorage" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:jstorage">JSTOR Folklore</a><span><br /></span><span>JSTOR itself is a full-text journal database which provides access to more than 500 titles in a wide range of disciplines, including African-American studies, anthropology, Asian studies, folklore, music, religion, and sociology. JSTOR Folklore covers five journals: </span><span>Asian Folklore Studies, Folklore, Journal of American Folklore, Ricerca Folklorica </span><span>and</span><span> Western Folklore</span><span>, from volume one to within circa five years of the most recent issue. These journals are also indexed by the MLA International Bibliography, with coverage beginning later than JSTOR’s  but continuing through the present.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~folkmyth/Project%20Muse" title="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~folkmyth/Project Muse">Project Muse</a><span><br /></span><span>Project Muse is a full-text collection of articles from over 200 scholarly journals in the humanities, arts, and social sciences. Coverage varies but generally includes recent years (e.g., 2003-present).<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span></span><strong><span>Specialized Resources</span></strong><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><strong>Online Bibliographic Management Program</strong><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:refworks" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:refworks">RefWorks</a><span> </span><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span>A Refworks guide is available at the URL:    </span><a class="style_13" href="http://hcl.harvard.edu/research/guides/refworks/" title="http://hcl.harvard.edu/research/guides/refworks/">http://hcl.harvard.edu/research/guides/refworks/</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span></span><strong>Online Dictionaries</strong><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:oxfordro" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:oxfordro">Oxford Reference Online: Mythology and Folklore</a><span><br /></span><span>(Choose „Mythology and Folklore.‰)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span></span><span><strong>Online Music</strong> <br /><br /></span><a class="style_14" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:smithglo" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:smithglo">Smithsonian Global Sound</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:aamusong" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:aamusong">African American Song</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><a class="style_11" href="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:naxosmus" title="http://nrs.harvard.edu/urn-3:hul.eresource:naxosmus">Naxos Music Library</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span> </span><span>For more information, contact Pam Matz, Widener Library Research Librarian, </span><a class="style_9" href="mailto:pmatz@fas.harvard.edu" title="mailto:pmatz@fas.harvard.edu">pmatz@fas.harvard.edu</a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"><span> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span><strong><span style="font-size:large">JOURNALS</span></strong><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><a class="style_16" href="http://www.americanfolk.com/" title="http://www.americanfolk.com/">American Folk</a></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><a class="style_18" href="http://www.panam.edu/faculty/mglazer/isclr/ContemporaryLegend.htm" title="http://www.panam.edu/faculty/mglazer/isclr/ContemporaryLegend.htm">Contemporary Legend</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><a class="style_18" href="http://afsnet.org/publications/jaf/" title="http://afsnet.org/publications/jaf/">Journal of American Folklore</a><span><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_7"><a class="style_18" href="http://websites.usu.edu/english/Document/index.asp?Parent=580" title="http://websites.usu.edu/english/Document/index.asp?Parent=580">Western Folklore</a></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>

</p>
</div></div></div>
  </div></section><div id="block-boxes-1389395993" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389395993"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389395993' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p>     </p></div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-solr-search-box" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_search_solr_search_box no-title"  module="boxes" delta="solr_search_box"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-solr_search_box' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><form class="search-block-form" action="/resources" method="post" id="search-block-form" accept-charset="UTF-8"><div><div class="container-inline">

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>

				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">  
  
  <ul class="nice-menu nice-menu-down nice-menu-primary-menu" id="nice-menu-primary-menu"><li class="menu-900 menu-path-front  first   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><span>HOME</span></a></li><li class="menu-6799 menuparent  menu-path-node-131471   even  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/about" ><span>About</span></a><span ><span>Brief History of F&M</span></a></li><li class="menu-7189 menu-path-node-138251   odd  "><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/warren-house" ><span>Warren House</span></a></li><li
