		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Secondary Field                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138206" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<em>“Folklore is a body of traditional belief, custom, and expression, handed down largely by word of mouth and circulating chiefly outside of commercial and academic means of communication and instruction. Every group bound together by common interests and purposes, whether educated or uneducated, rural or urban, possesses a body of traditions which may be called its folklore. Into these traditions enter many elements, individual, popular, and even "literary," but all are absorbed and assimilated through repetition and variation into a pattern which has value and continuity for the group as a whole.”</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="text-align:right">
	Benjamin A. Botkin, 1938
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>On this page:</strong>
</p>

<ul><li>
		Introduction
	</li>
	<li>
		Frequently Asked Questions
	</li>
	<li>
		Required Courses
	</li>
	<li>
		Contact
	</li>
</ul><p class="paragraph_style_2">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	<strong>Introduction</strong>
</p>

<p>
	Folklore and Mythology as a discipline focuses on the study of society, past or present, through its cultural documents and artifacts—its folklore—and uses a variety of methodologies drawn from the humanities and social sciences to understand them. To concentrate on a society’s folklore and mythology (on sub-national as well as national levels) is to understand its traditional self-definition through its myths, epics, ballads, folktales, legends, beliefs, and other cultural phenomena, including music, song, and dance.  Studying a group’s folklore shows how it identifies itself in relation to other groups. 
</p>

<p>
	Inherently interdisciplinary, the study of Folklore and Mythology often draws resources from several disciplines, while maintaining its own methodological lens.  Students wishing to meet the requirements for a secondary field in Folklore and Mythology must take Culture and Belief 16. Performance, Tradition, and Cultural Studies: An Introduction to Folklore and Mythology, one of the F&amp;M 90 topical seminars in the field, and three other courses chosen from Folklore and Mythology and/or cross-listed courses as listed in the Course Catalog and on the Folklore and Mythology website. 
</p>

<p>
	<strong>Students wishing for a particularly focused and coherent program of study should make an appointment with the Head Tutor or Chair of the program to discuss options.</strong>  Students who notify the Head Tutor early on of their intention to pursue a secondary field in Folklore and Mythology will insure that they are invited to special lectures, film showings, lunches and receptions.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	<strong>FAQ</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>Do all courses need to be taken for letter grade? If so, is there a grade minimum?</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="padding-left:30px">
	Yes, courses need to be taken for a letter grade, with the exception of approved Freshman Seminars. Grades should be B- or above.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>Will relevant freshman seminars count?</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="padding-left:30px">
	Yes, relevant Freshman Seminars will count.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>Can courses from study abroad or Harvard summer school count?</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="padding-left:30px">
	Harvard summer school courses can count and study abroad courses taught by our faculty (i.e. in the summer) can count. Students may petition to count at most one study abroad course that is not taught by our faculty by presenting syllabi and papers from the course to the Head Tutor or Chairman.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>When do you want students to come and meet with you? Do they have to meet with you before they have finished their requirements?</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="padding-left:30px">
	Students are encouraged to meet with the Head Tutor to discuss their plans for pursuing a Secondary Field in F&amp;M. By doing so, they will not only receive advice on courses, they will also be invited to concentration activities and events.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<strong>Does "signing up" give students preferential access to limited-enrollment courses?</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1" style="padding-left:30px">
	Preferential access to limited enrollment courses will be determined by each faculty member for his or her own course.
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	<strong>Required Courses (5)</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	Two half-courses:           
</p>

<ul><li>
		Culture and Belief 16. Performance, Tradition and Cultural Studies: An Introduction to Folklore and Mythology. Surveys the major forms of folklore (e.g., myths, legends, epics, beliefs, rituals, festivals) and the theoretical approaches used to understand and interpret “texts” drawn from the world of traditional expression and ritualized behavior. (Mitchell)
	</li>
	<li>
		Folklore and Mythology 90: focused seminars examine specific topics in the field
	</li>
</ul><p>
	<span>Three half-courses from among those offered in Folklore &amp; Mythology or the cross-listings.</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="style"> </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<strong>Contact:</strong>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	Ruth Goldstein, Head Tutor<br />103 Warren House<br /><a href="mailto:ruth_goldstein@fas.harvard.edu">ruth_goldstein@fas.harvard.edu</a>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	 
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390597504' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168456" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/deborah-african-hanging2.jpg?m=1492187800">deborah-african-hanging2.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/deborah-african-hanging2.jpg?m=1499747343&amp;itok=65Pz22m-" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-46866"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics"  class="active-trail active"><span>Academics</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-46871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/advising-0" ><span>Advising</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-47651"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics/courses" ><span>Courses</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-48431"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" ><span>Concentration Requirements</span></a></li><li class="leaf active-trail active-trail menu-depth-2 menu-item-48486"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/secondary-field"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Secondary Field</span></a></li><li class="last leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48526"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/swapna-dev-memorial-book-prize" ><span>The Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>

			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">

					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Senior Theses &amp; Senior Projects                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138181" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1">During the senior year, we expect students concentrating in Folklore &amp; Mythology to demonstrate their command of cultural theory an analysis.  In the senior project option, <strong>Folklore and Mythology 96r</strong>, such competence may be demonstrated through, for example, a performance, exhibit, or written analysis, usually in connection with specific Folklore and Mythology courses (or related courses approved by the Head Tutor). Students who wish to be considered for high honors or highest honors write a Senior Honors Thesis, an extended research project carried out over two semesters as <strong>Folklore and Mythology 99</strong>, under the supervision of a faculty advisor. </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>Senior Thesis Deadlines</strong></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">Concentrators writing theses in the Folklore and Mythology program will be required to give their advisers the designated thesis parts by the following deadlines:</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4">1. PROSPECTUS DUE: Last Thursday in April (Junior year)</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4">2. PRESENT TO COMMITTEE: early May (Junior year), at Degree Meeting</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4">3. FIRST CHAPTER DUE: first Friday in December (Senior year)</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4">4.FINAL DEADLINE: Thursday before Spring Recess (Senior Year)</p>
<p class="paragraph_style_6"> </p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3">N.B. Joint concentrators must follow the calendars of the other departments. Those who are graduating mid-year should consult the Head Tutor for specific instructions regarding deadlines.</p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

<meta name="description" content="Folklore and Mythology encourages close work with a faculty adviser and the Head Tutor in designing the Special Field. The goal of the collaboration is to determine a program of courses that focuses on an area, such as those listed below. These courses do not necessarily fall in a single department.  The list below is not exhaustive, but is meant to give a sense of the wide range of options. " />

These courses do not necessarily fall in a single department.  The list below is not exhaustive, but is meant to give a sense of the wide range of options. " />

					<!--header regions beg-->
			<header id="header" class="clearfix" role="banner">
			 <div id="header-container">
				 <div id="header-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display three-col clearfix">
					  					  <div class="region region-header-second"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-info" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_info no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_info"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_info' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><h1><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology</a></h1>
    <h2>Harvard University</h2>
    <p>
    <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/contact_owner" >Contact</a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  <div class="region region-header-first"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-site-logo" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_site_logo no-title"  module="boxes" delta="site_logo"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-site_logo' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" ><img src="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/greenman-red-sm2.jpg?m=1491626182" width="132" height="149" alt="The Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology" /></a></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>					  					  				 </div>

				  <!--main menu region beg-->
		  <div id="menu-bar" class="nav region-menu-bar clearfix"><nav id="block-os-primary-menu" class="block block-os no-title menu-wrapper menu-bar-wrapper clearfix"  module="os" delta="primary-menu">

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Special Fields                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138171" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style">Folklore and Mythology encourages close work with a faculty adviser and the Head Tutor in designing the </span><span class="style">Special Field</span><span class="style">. The goal of the collaboration is to determine a program of courses that focuses on an area, such as those listed below. These courses do not necessarily fall in a single department.  The list below is not exhaustive, but is meant to give a sense of the wide range of options. </span><span class="style"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span style="font-size:medium"><strong><span class="style_3">Some Special Field Options</span><span class="style_4">:</span></strong></span><span class="style_5"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">African</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">English &amp; American</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Medieval Latin</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Sociology</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Afro-American</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Ethnomusicology</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Performance</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Visual &amp; Environmental Studies</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Anthropology</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">German</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Psychology</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Women's Studies</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Celtic</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Greek (ancient or modern)</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Romance Languages </span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Classics</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">History</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Sanskrit &amp; Indian Studies </span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Cultural Studies</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">History &amp; Science</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Scandinavian </span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">East Asian</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Linguistics</span><span class="style_6"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Slavic</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1389736840" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389736840"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389736840' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-163036" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/sioux2.jpg?m=1491647790">sioux2.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/sioux2.jpg?m=1499734975&amp;itok=NmSTW8Fc" width="200" height="179" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail menu-item-48451"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/special-fields"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Special Fields</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-3 menu-item-48461"><a 			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Study Abroad                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138196" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style">Many students in Folklore &amp; Mythology decide to spend part of their undergraduate education studying abroad. Students should explore the possibilities at the <a href="http://oie.fas.harvard.edu/home">Office of International Education</a></span><a class="style_1" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/%7Eoip" title="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~oip"> </a><span class="style">(OIE; located at 77 Dunster Street) as early as possible and then see the Head Tutor to discuss possible courses and a specific plan of study. Students must file petitions for credit for study out of residence with the OIP before leaving (check with OIP, 6-2722, for deadlines).<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">The Head Tutor must approve courses to be taken for concentration credit. Studying abroad for a full year can complicate meeting degree requirements; however, the rewards of a year abroad sometimes outweigh the difficulty of struggling to fit in all the requirements for the degree. It is important to seek advice from the Head Tutor and OIE advisers as early as possible, to plan ahead. Students are required to bring back all relevant materials (syllabi, papers written, etc.) from courses that are expected to count for concentration credit. If your instructor insists on keeping your papers, make copies. If any questions about credit should arise, it is important that you should have this information. (Grades from study-abroad programs will not be counted in students’ grade point averages, nor be taken into account when honors recommendations are made.) Students who are planning to apply for fellowships in their senior year should consult with the House tutors about the kinds of recommendations they should seek before leaving and while abroad. Please see the Head Tutor well in advance of deadlines to discuss plans.</span><span class="style_2"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style">Click here for the <a href="http://oie.fas.harvard.edu/home">Office of International Education</a></span><a class="style_1" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/%7Eoip" title="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~oip"></a><span class="style"> website.</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1389736713" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1389736713"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1389736713' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-163026" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/runestone.jpg?m=1491647789">runestone.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/runestone.jpg?m=1499733698&amp;itok=8ytrdn_3" width="200" height="179" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail <meta property="og:title" content="Style, Rules &amp; Requirements" />
<meta name="description" content="One thing few thesis writers realize is that production constitutes an entirely separate stage of the thesis project. Give yourself plenty of time to produce clean copies of your thesis.  It is NOT advised that you leave printing until the day the thesis is due, as unforeseen printing problems are not an excuse for handing in work late.  Leave yourself time for proofreading a printed copy, as well.  Readers grading the thesis may find that errors reflect poorly on the work." />
<meta property="og:description" content="One thing few thesis writers realize is that production constitutes an entirely separate stage of the thesis project. Give yourself plenty of time to produce clean copies of your thesis.  It is NOT advised that you leave printing until the day the thesis is due, as unforeseen printing problems are not an excuse for handing in work late.  Leave yourself time for proofreading a printed copy, as well.  Readers grading the thesis may find that errors reflect poorly on the work." />
<title>Style, Rules &amp; Requirements | The Committee on Degrees in Folklore & Mythology</title>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/senior-theses-senior-projects" >SENIOR THESES &amp; SENIOR PROJECTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Style, Rules &amp; Requirements                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138241" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_4">One thing few thesis writers realize is that production constitutes an entirely separate stage of the thesis project. Give yourself plenty of time to produce clean copies of your thesis.  It is NOT advised that you leave printing until the day the thesis is due, as unforeseen printing problems are not an excuse for handing in work late.  Leave yourself time for proofreading a printed copy, as well.  Readers grading the thesis may find that errors reflect poorly on the work.</span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_4">Refer to the section on thesis regulations below for format requirements. Again, those enrolled in Senior Tutorials outside of the Folklore &amp; Mythology program must observe the guidelines of their department.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_2"><span class="style_4">All theses submitted to the Folklore &amp; Mythology program must conform to the following requirements:</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_4">LENGTH:</span></strong><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">The recommended length is 40-60 pages  (not including appendices, if applicable)</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_4">MARGINS:</span></strong><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">Please leave a lefthand margin of 1.5"</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_4">PAPER:</span></strong><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">Use archival quality, acid-free paper for all copies</span><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_3"><strong><span class="style_4">COPIES:</span></strong><span class="style_4"><br /></span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_3"><span class="style_4">One will remain in the F&amp;M library; one will go to the Harvard College library archives (if magna or above); one will be returned to you, if you wish. (No copies will have comments written by readers.  Readers are asked to submit comments separately.)<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4"></span><strong>BINDERS:</strong></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">Please </span><span class="style_4">do not</span><span class="style_4"> use any type of binder when turning in the thesis.  </span></p>
<p style="padding-left:30px" class="paragraph_style_4"><span class="style_4">Do not staple or hole-punch any of the copies of the thesis.  We would also prefer that you not use paper-clips of any kind, including binder-clips.  Please put each copy in a folder or envelope.<br /></span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_1"><span class="style_4"> </span></p>
<p class="paragraph_style_5"><span class="style_4">(For a reminder of Deadlines, see the main <a href="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/folklore/senior-theses-senior-projects">Senior Thesis</a></span><a class="style" href="http://www.fas.harvard.edu/~folkmyth/Folk_%26_Myth/Senior_Theses.html" title="Senior_Theses.html"></a><span class="style_4"> page.)</span></p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

		<div id="columns" class="clearfix">
			<div class="hg-container">
				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      The Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138246" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<span class="Bullet">The Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize in Folklore &amp; Mythology was established in 2007 according to the wishes of her husband, and supported by his generous gift. The prize honors the interest that Swapna Dev had in the field and her connection to the Harvard Committee on Degrees in Folklore &amp; Mythology, where she was a visiting scholar from 1983 to 1985, under head tutor Prof. Hugh Flick.</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<span class="Bullet">The Book Prize will be awarded annually to the graduating senior whose thesis receives the highest marks from its readers. (Winners will be listed below.) </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	<span class="Bullet"> </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="Bullet">Brief bio of Swapna Dev [1949-2001]</span></strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><strong><span class="Bullet"> </span></strong></span><img alt="" height="129" src="http://projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_small/public/folklore/files/swapnadev-bw_0.jpg?itok=P7dUFB91" title="" width="93" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_1">
	<span class="Bullet">After getting her B.A. and M.A. in English from Delhi University, Swapna taught for many years at the Jesus &amp; Mary College, one of the leading colleges of the university. She was a visiting scholar in Folklore &amp; Mythology at Harvard University from 1983 to 1985. At Harvard, Swapna worked on the metaphysical symbolism of Buddhist Stupas. Swapna and her family settled in San Diego, California, in 1988, and she became a freelance writer. She is survived by her husband and three daughters. </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_2">
	<span class="Bullet"> </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>Winners of the Swapna Dev Memorial Book Prize</strong></span></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span style="font-size:small"><em>(Thank you to Mark Smith, Sharon Nicoletto, and Holly Hutchison for the photos)</em></span></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2017:</strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“Moving Forward, Looking Back: Comparative Folklore and Mythology in a Computational Age</em></span><span class="Bullet"><em>”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="padding-left:30px">
	Monica Marion
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="576" width="573" alt="Monica Marion with parents." class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/img_4615_2_01.jpg?m=1502311000&amp;itok=NkaoJ_xw" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	(above: Monica Marion, center, with parents.)
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2016:</strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“'I'm Done For!': Petrushka in Ballet and Puppet Theater</em></span><span class="Bullet"><em>”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="padding-left:30px">
	Isabella Palange
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="360" width="480" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/img_3699_copy.jpg?m=1476389901&amp;itok=jnBcEdP_" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet">(above: Isabella Palange, right, with thesis advisor Daria Khitrova, left, and Deborah Foster of Folklore &amp; Mythology, center)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="360" width="270" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/img_3689_copy.jpg?m=1476389923&amp;itok=IbOmBFzY" alt="" title="" /> <img height="360" width="270" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/img_3694_copy.jpg?m=1476389937&amp;itok=uNyxt6cL" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet">(above: left, Isabella Palange; right, Isabella with her mother, standing, and sister.)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2015:  (no award)</strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2014:</strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“'We Thought it Was Dry Land': Myth and Tall Tale in the Sea Narratives of Baba Batra 73a-74b”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="padding-left:30px">
	Daniel Frim
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong><img height="299" width="430" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/2014-swapnadev.jpg?m=1426694088&amp;itok=ddVCVvjX" alt="" title="" /></strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet">(above: Daniel Frim, center, with his father and grandmother.)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p>
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2013:</strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“Trickster Visits the White House: Liminality and Political Redefinition in The Onion's Coverage of the 2012 Presidential Campaign”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="margin-left:40px">
	William Goulston
</p>

<p>
	and
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“Nameless: the Story of Rumplestiltskin's Daughter”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="margin-left:40px">
	Rebecca Harbeson
</p>

<p>
	<img height="320" width="263" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2013-swapnadev-2.jpg?m=1426626499&amp;itok=8e8qkIE_" alt="" title="" /><img height="334" width="248" style="font-size: initial;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2013-swapnadev-1.jpg?m=1426626499&amp;itok=2J2O7vBr" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p>
	<span style="font-size:small"><em>(above: Deborah Foster with William Goulston, left; Rebecca Harbeson, right.)</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="Bullet">2012:</span></strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><em>“Following la Difunta”</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3" style="margin-left:40px">
	Meredith Keffer
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet">and</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_5">
	<em><span class="Bullet">“Tere Tohorā Tere Tangata: </span>Where Whales Journey People Follow”</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_6" style="margin-left:40px">
	<span class="Bullet">Caroline Lowe</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"> <img height="317" width="431" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/2012-swapnadev.jpg?m=1426626500&amp;itok=2fY5qVzn" alt="" title="" /></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet">(above: Meredith Keffer, Deborah Foster, Caroline Lowe, front; Maria Tatar, Steve Mitchell, Holly Hutchison, back.)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="Bullet">2011:</span></strong></span></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_7">
	<em><span class="Bullet">“The Right Words: Encounters with </span>Meaning in Prayer”</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_7" style="margin-left:40px">
	<span class="Bullet">Molly Elder Moses</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="321" width="414" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/2011-swapnadev.jpg?m=1426694088&amp;itok=ec3ceSEj" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em>(above: Molly Moses, with her adviser, Jon Levenson.)</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span class="Bullet" style="font-size:large"><strong>2010:</strong></span></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_8">
	<em><span class="Bullet">“Invoking the Nation: Reflexive Tradition </span>in Early Modern Japan”</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_8" style="margin-left:40px">
	<span class="Bullet">Rachel Storch</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"> <img height="393" width="304" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2010-swapnadev.jpg?m=1426626500&amp;itok=zBpngPq1" alt="" title="" /></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet">(above: Rachel Storch.)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:large"><strong><span class="Bullet">2009:</span></strong></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_9">
	<span class="Bullet">"Grace Church" (documentary video) &amp; </span><em>"The Sound of Heaven: Testimony and Intercessory Prayer in a Houston Megachurch"</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_9" style="margin-left:40px">
	<span class="Bullet">Jennifer Malin</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 <img height="227" width="315" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2009-swapnadev-2.jpg?m=1426626500&amp;itok=3qqIQkSJ" alt="" title="" /><img height="281" width="267" style="font-size: initial;" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2009-swapnadev-1.jpg?m=1426626500&amp;itok=9dKW24nG" alt="" title="" /> 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em><span class="Bullet"> (above: Jennifer Malin, left; Ken Dev, Joseph Harris, Deborah Foster, right.)</span></em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>2008:</strong></span> </span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_10">
	<span class="Bullet">"Gregory the Great and the Myth of the Gregorian </span>Chant"
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_10" style="padding-left:30px">
	Jhoshua Friedman
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="262" width="462" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-large" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_large/public/folklore/files/2008-swapnadev-1.jpg?m=1426626230&amp;itok=c71-Jr1Q" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em>(above, from left to right: Jhosh Friedman; Jhosh's father; Jhosh's mother; Deborah Foster; Joseph Harris; Jhosh's thesis adviser, Tom Kelly; Steve Mitchell; friend of Ken and Swapna Dev, Sharon Nicoletto.)</em></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_10">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	 
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span class="Bullet"><span style="font-size:large"><strong>2007:</strong></span></span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_9">
	<em><span class="Bullet">"The Gaelic Waulking Songs of Mairi nighean </span>Alasdair: A Preliminary Translation and Classification With a Discussion of Voice and Gender”</em>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_9" style="margin-left:40px">
	<span class="Bullet">Margaret Harrison</span>
</p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<img height="205" width="288" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2007-swapnadev-1.jpg?m=1426626501&amp;itok=AXGaJJnO" alt="" title="" /><img height="209" width="294" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-medium" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_medium/public/folklore/files/2007-swapnadev-3.jpg?m=1426626987&amp;itok=oEzb7GnO" alt="" title="" /></p>

<p class="paragraph_style_3">
	<span style="font-size:small"><em>(above: Margaret Harrison and Ken Dev, left; Mark Smith, Sharon Nicoletto, Ken Dev, right.)</em></span>
</p>
</div></div></div>  </div>

				<div id="content-column" role="main">
					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/news-events" >CALENDAR &amp; EVENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Symposiums &amp; Conferences                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-137976" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p>Folklore &amp; Mythology holds an annual event aimed at exploring a thematic topic.  These events range from one-day symposia, to multi-day conferences.</p><p> </p><p><img height="744" width="1000" class="media-element file-default file-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/fm_symposium_poster_revised2.png?m=1499882345&amp;itok=RpepVtrF" alt="" title="" /></p><p><strong>Folkore and Mythology in and Beyond Harvard: F&amp;M at 50</strong> is a symposium that will be held on Thursday, March 2, 2017 and Friday, March 3, 2017.  See the event page for more details!  (Free and open to the public.)</p><p> </p><p> </p></div></div></div>  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

								  <!--sidebar first region beg-->
				  <div class="region region-sidebar-first sidebar"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-boxes-1390600344" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_media no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1390600344"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1390600344' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><div id="file-168531" class="file file-image file-image-jpeg">

          <h2 class="element-invisible"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/walters-symposium.jpg?m=1492187826">walters-symposium.jpg</a></h2>
      
  
  <div class="content">
    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/walters-symposium.jpg?m=1499909549&amp;itok=fFAUKfi7" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

  
</div>
</div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-1415209073" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_html no-title"  module="boxes" delta="1415209073"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-1415209073' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><p></p>
<p><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar"></a><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar">Current Calendar</a></p>
<p><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences">Symposiums &amp; Conferences</a><a href="http://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/calendar"></a></p>
<p></p></div></div></div>
  </div></div><div id="block-boxes-os-pages-section-nav" class="block block-boxes block-boxes-os_boxes_sectionnav section-nav no-title"  module="boxes" delta="os_pages_section_nav"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><div id='boxes-box-os_pages_section_nav' class='boxes-box'><div class="boxes-box-content"><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first last expanded active-trail active-trail menu-depth-1 menu-item-48301"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/symposiums-conferences"  class="active-trail active active"><span>Symposiums & Conferences</span></a><ul class="menu clearfix"><li class="first leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-182991"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/folklore-and-beyond-harvard-folklore-mythology-50" ><span>2017: Folklore and Mythology In and Beyond Harvard: F&M at 50</span></a></li><li class="collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-142871"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/celebrating-another-harmony-south-asian-folklore-21st-century" ><span>2016: Celebrating Another Harmony: South Asian Folklore in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-93471"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2015-netlore-globalizing-folklore-digital-world" ><span>2015: NETLORE: Globalizing Folklore in a Digital World</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48381"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-old-norse-mythology-its-comparative-contexts" ><span>2013: Old Norse Mythology in its Comparative Contexts</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48376"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2013-upside-down-inside-out-festivals-transgressive-performance" ><span>2013: Upside Down & Inside Out (Festivals as Transgressive Performance)</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48371"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2012-grimm-legacies" ><span>2012: Grimm Legacies</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48366"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2011-african-dance-diaspora" ><span>2011: African Dance Diaspora</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48356"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-singers-tales-21st-century" ><span>2010: Singers & Tales in the 21st Century</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48361"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2010-fire-mountain-bluegrass-symposium" ><span>2010: Fire on the Mountain: A Bluegrass Symposium</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48341"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2009-legends-landscape-narratives-nature" ><span>2009: Legends of Landscape, Narratives of Nature</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48336"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2008-folklore-nationalism" ><span>2008: Folklore & Nationalism</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48331"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2007-feminist-folklore-masculine-myths" ><span>2007: Feminist Folklore & Masculine Myths</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48326"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2006-performing-folklore" ><span>2006: Performing Folklore</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48311"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2005-folklore-fantasy-film" ><span>2005: Folklore, Fantasy & Film</span></a></li><li class="leaf menu-depth-2 menu-item-48306"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2004-dance-drum-drink" ><span>2004: Dance, Drum & Drink</span></a></li><li class="last collapsed menu-depth-2 menu-item-170936"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/2003-all-eyez-me-tupac-shakur-and-search-modern-folk-hero" ><span>2003: "All Eyez on Me: Tupac Shakur and the Search for the Modern Folk Hero"</span></a></li></ul></li></ul></div></div></div>
  </div></div></div></div>				  <!--sidebar first region end-->
        
				
			</div>
		</div>

					<div class="content-inner">
					  <div class="breadcrumb"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/" >HOME</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/academics" >ACADEMICS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/concentration-requirements" >CONCENTRATION REQUIREMENTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> <a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/senior-theses-senior-projects" >SENIOR THESES &amp; SENIOR PROJECTS</a> <span>&#47;</span> </div>
													              <a name="main-content"></a>
															<header id="main-content-header">
									<a name="main-content"></a>
                    <h1 id="page-title">
                      Thesis Prospectus                    </h1>
                </header>
														
															<!--front panel regions beg-->
								<div id="content-panels" class="at-panel gpanel panel-display content clearfix">
									<div class="region region-content-top"><div class="region-inner clearfix"><div id="block-os-pages-main-content" class="block block-os-pages no-title"  module="os_pages" delta="main_content"><div class="block-inner clearfix">  
  
  <div class="block-content content"><article id="node-138226" class="node node-page article clearfix" role="article">
  
  
  
  <div class="node-content">
    <div class="field field-name-body field-type-text-with-summary field-label-hidden view-mode-full"><div class="field-items"><div class="field-item even"><p><span>A thesis prospectus with initial bibliography, signed by the thesis adviser, is due in late April of your Junior year. A prospectus is a statement about your refined topic and your proposed argument. In addition, the prospectus should include a summary of what you hope to accomplish through further research.</span></p>
<p><span>The Head Tutor will alert you to the deadline at the start of the spring semester.  You will also be expected to attend the second half of the Committee Degree Meeting in early May, and present your prospectus to the committee members.  They will give feedback on the proposal, and make suggestions regarding sources, approaches, and people to consult.</span></p>
<p><span>If you revise your prospectus during the summer before the Senior year, you should make sure to present a revised copy to the Head Tutor.</span></p></div></div></div><table class="os-files-other-list">
<tbody>
 <tr class="odd"><td class="mime mime-doc"><img class="file-icon" alt="" src="/profiles/openscholar/modules/os/modules/os_files/icons/x-office-document.svg" /></td><td class="file"><a href="https://folkmyth.fas.harvard.edu/files/folklore/files/prospectus_13-14.doc" >prospectus_13-14.doc</a></td><td class="size">24 KB</td> </tr>
</tbody>
</table>
  </div>

  
  
  </article>
</div>
  </div></div></div></div>																																			</div>
								<!--front panel regions end-->
													
											</div>
				</div>

    <img class="image-style-os-files-xxlarge" src="//static.projects.iq.harvard.edu/files/styles/os_files_xxlarge/public/folklore/files/maya-calendar-dragon.jpg?m=1499784932&amp;itok=rQY27OlY" width="200" height="180" alt="" title="" />  </div>

</div></div></div>
